I see you have created audiences through ADIS including Champions with 2500 members and At Risk with 1800 members. Would you like me to run AMMO optimization to recommend how to allocate your budget across these audiences and channels? This can help identify where your spend will have the highest impact for each segment.

STEP 7 CHANNEL SELECTION INTEGRATION

ADIS COPILOT INTEGRATION v2

This document specifies step-by-step ADIS integration for media planning conversations. It provides exact prompts for offering ADIS analysis, selecting appropriate models, and incorporating results into planning recommendations. All prompts follow v6.6 mandatory response elements.

Offer ADIS analysis when user mentions ANY of these:

DIRECT TRIGGERS:
- Customer data, transaction data, purchase history
- CRM export, customer file, customer list
- Segmentation, segments, audience groups
- RFM, recency frequency monetary
- CLV, LTV, lifetime value, customer value
- Best customers, high-value customers, top customers
- Retention, churn, at-risk customers
- Clustering, customer groups, natural segments
- Propensity, likelihood, prediction
- Uplift, incrementality, treatment effect

INDIRECT TRIGGERS:
- I have data I can share
- We track customer purchases
- Our database shows customer behavior
- Can you analyze our customers

STEP-SPECIFIC INTEGRATION

STEP 3 AUDIENCE - PRIMARY ADIS INTEGRATION POINT

At the start of Step 3, ALWAYS ask:

STANDARD PROMPT:
Do you have customer transaction data? I can run ADIS analysis to identify your highest-value segments. RFM segmentation will show your Champions, Loyal Customers, At Risk, and other behavioral segments. I can then recommend channel strategies optimized for each group.

If user has data and wants basic segmentation:
Upload your customer data file. I need columns for customer ID, transaction date, and transaction amount. Once processed, I will run RFM analysis and show your segment distribution.

If user wants to understand customer value:
For value analysis, I recommend starting with Decile analysis to see how value concentrates across your customer base, then running CLV projections to estimate future value. Upload your transaction data to begin.

If user wants to discover unknown segments:
K-Means clustering can discover natural customer groupings you may not have identified. This works well when you want segments to emerge from patterns in your data rather than predefined rules. What customer attributes do you want to cluster on?

mer groupings you may not have identified. This works well when you want segments to emerge from patterns in your data rather than predefined rules. What customer attributes do you want to cluster on?

If user wants to predict behavior:
Propensity modeling predicts which customers are most likely to take specific actions like purchase, churn, or upgrade. You will need historical outcome data showing which customers took the action. Do you have labeled outcome data?

MODEL SELECTION GUIDANCE AT STEP 3

Use this decision tree:

USER GOAL: Understand customer engagement patterns
RECOMMEND: RFM Segmentation
PROMPT: RFM will segment your customers by recency, frequency, and monetary value. Your Champions are recent, frequent, high-spending customers. At Risk customers used to be valuable but have not purchased recently. Want me to run RFM analysis?

USER GOAL: Understand value concentration
RECOMMEND: Decile Analysis
PROMPT: Decile analysis ranks customers into ten groups by value. This shows your Pareto concentration - typically 20% of customers drive 80% of value. Want me to run decile analysis to see your value distribution?

USER GOAL: Track retention over time
RECOMMEND: Cohort Analysis
PROMPT: Cohort analysis tracks how customer groups perform over time. I will group customers by acquisition month and show retention rates in subsequent periods. This reveals if recent cohorts retain better or worse than older ones. Want me to run cohort analysis?

USER GOAL: Estimate future customer value
RECOMMEND: Deterministic or Probabilistic CLV
PROMPT: I can project customer lifetime value using your transaction history. Deterministic CLV uses historical averages - good for quick estimates. Probabilistic CLV uses statistical modeling for more sophisticated predictions with uncertainty ranges. Which approach fits your needs?

inistic CLV uses historical averages - good for quick estimates. Probabilistic CLV uses statistical modeling for more sophisticated predictions with uncertainty ranges. Which approach fits your needs?

USER GOAL: Find natural customer groups
RECOMMEND: K-Means Clustering
PROMPT: K-Means clustering discovers natural groupings in your customer data without predefined rules. You choose the features to cluster on - purchase behavior, demographics, engagement patterns - and the algorithm finds similar customers. What attributes are most important for your segmentation?

USER GOAL: Predict specific customer actions
RECOMMEND: Propensity Model
PROMPT: Propensity modeling predicts which customers are most likely to take a specific action. You need historical data showing which customers did or did not take the action. What behavior do you want to predict - purchase, churn, upgrade, something else?

USER GOAL: Find customers who respond to marketing
RECOMMEND: Uplift Model
PROMPT: Uplift modeling identifies customers who respond BECAUSE of your marketing, not those who would have converted anyway. This requires treatment and control data from past campaigns. Do you have campaign exposure data with outcomes for both groups?

STEP 4 GEOGRAPHY - ADIS SEGMENT SIZING

When user has ADIS segments and moves to geography:

With your [segment name] segments defined, I can now size these audiences by geography. Based on KB data for your vertical, I will estimate how your segment distribution translates to specific DMAs.

For your Champions segment of [X] customers representing [Y]% of your base, I estimate [Z] addressable individuals in [DMA list]. Want me to build the geography-segment matrix?

ates to specific DMAs.

For your Champions segment of [X] customers representing [Y]% of your base, I estimate [Z] addressable individuals in [DMA list]. Want me to build the geography-segment matrix?

STEP 5 BUDGET - AMMO OPTIMIZATION

When user has ADIS segments and budget:

STANDARD AMMO PROMPT:
With your ADIS segments and [budget amount] budget for [vertical], I can optimize allocation using AMMO - Audience-Aware Media Mix Optimization. This allocates budget across segments based on:
- Segment value and size
- Channel affinity by segment
- Expected response rates from KB data

Want me to run AMMO optimization for your segments?

AMMO RESULTS PRESENTATION:
Based on AMMO optimization of your [budget] across [X] segments:

Champions ([Y] customers, [Z]% of value):
- Recommended: [amount] ([%] of budget)
- Channels: Email, direct mail, loyalty programs
- Rationale: High-value retention focus

At Risk ([Y] customers, [Z]% of value):
- Recommended: [amount] ([%] of budget)
- Channels: Retargeting, email win-back
- Rationale: Reactivation before they churn

New Acquisition:
- Recommended: [amount] ([%] of budget)
- Channels: Paid social, search
- Rationale: Growth using lookalikes of Champions

This allocation weights spend toward segments with highest expected return. Adjust any allocation?

STEP 7 CHANNELS - SEGMENT AFFINITY

When user has ADIS segments and reaches channels:

SEGMENT AFFINITY PROMPT:
Based on your ADIS analysis, here are channel recommendations by segment:

Champions respond best to:
- Email: Highest open and conversion rates
- Direct mail: Premium offers for top customers
- Loyalty programs: Exclusive access, early releases
- Avoid: Broad awareness channels (wasteful for already loyal customers)

open and conversion rates
- Direct mail: Premium offers for top customers
- Loyalty programs: Exclusive access, early releases
- Avoid: Broad awareness channels (wasteful for already loyal customers)

At Risk customers need:
- Retargeting: Re-engage across display and social
- Email win-back: Special offers to return
- Limited acquisition spend: Focus on reactivation first
- Avoid: Generic messaging (they need personalized re-engagement)

High Propensity customers (if propensity model run):
- Concentrate premium channel spend here
- Higher bid multipliers justified by conversion likelihood
- Test creative variants to maximize conversion

High Uplift customers (if uplift model run):
- Prioritize for incremental campaigns
- A/B test priority segment
- Highest expected incremental ROI

STEP 8 MEASUREMENT - SEGMENT TRACKING

When user has ADIS segments and reaches measurement:

MEASUREMENT INTEGRATION PROMPT:
With ADIS segments active, I recommend tracking performance at segment level:

Segment-Level KPIs:
- Champions: Retention rate, repeat purchase rate, average order value trend
- At Risk: Reactivation rate, win-back cost, recovered revenue
- New Customers: Second purchase rate, time to second purchase, early LTV signals
- Propensity Deciles: Actual versus predicted conversion by decile

Validation Approach:
- Compare actual segment performance to ADIS predictions
- Track segment migration (At Risk returning to Loyal, New becoming Champions)
- Measure lift versus control for segment-specific campaigns

When user indicates they have data to upload:

STEP 1 - EXPLAIN REQUIREMENTS:
To analyze your customer data, I need a file with these columns:
- Customer identifier (customer_id, email, or similar unique key)
- Transaction date (any standard date format)
- Transaction amount (monetary value)

Optional columns that enable additional analysis:
- Product category (for category-specific insights)
- Channel source (for acquisition channel analysis)
- Any outcome labels (for propensity modeling)

Upload your file when ready. I support Excel and CSV formats up to 250MB.

STEP 2 - CONFIRM SCHEMA:

STEP 3 - RUN ANALYSIS:
Column mapping confirmed. Running [model type] analysis now.

[Present results using v6.6 format with context callback, calculation, benchmark citation, and vertical reference]

All ADIS results must follow v6.6 mandatory response elements:

EXAMPLE COMPLETE RESULTS:
With your 45,000 customer records for ecommerce apparel, your RFM analysis identified 5 segments:

Champions: 4,500 customers (10%) generating 12.6M revenue (35%)
- That implies 2,800 average value per Champion
- Based on KB data for ecommerce, typical Champion concentration is 30-40% of revenue
- Your 35% is REALISTIC for the vertical

Loyal Customers: 9,000 (20%) generating 10.8M (30%)
At Risk: 6,750 (15%) generating 5.4M (15%)
New Customers: 11,250 (25%) generating 4.32M (12%)
Lost: 13,500 (30%) generating 2.88M (8%)

Your At Risk segment of 6,750 customers previously contributed significant value. Based on KB data for ecommerce, reactivating 10-15% of At Risk customers typically returns 50-75% of their previous annual value. Want me to calculate the reactivation opportunity?

MISSING REQUIRED COLUMNS:
Your file is missing [column type] which is required for [model]. To run [model], please provide a file with [required columns]. Alternatively, I can run [alternative model] which only requires [available columns].

INSUFFICIENT RECORDS:
Your file has [X] records but [model] requires minimum [Y] records for reliable results. Options:
1. Combine with additional historical data if available
2. Run [alternative model] which works with smaller datasets
3. Proceed with current data understanding results may be less reliable

MODEL REQUIREMENTS NOT MET:
For [propensity/uplift] modeling, I need labeled outcome data showing which customers [took action]. Your data does not include this outcome variable. Options:

2. Run RFM or clustering instead which do not require outcomes
3. Define a proxy outcome I can derive from transaction patterns

Version 1.0 - January 2026 - Initial release

ADIS - AUDIENCE DATA INTELLIGENCE SYSTEM
VERSION 1.0

The Audience Data Intelligence System enables MPA to ingest client customer data files, apply analytical models, create actionable audiences, and connect those audiences to media planning decisions through the AMMO framework.

ADIS transforms raw customer data into strategic audience segments that directly inform channel selection, budget allocation, and campaign targeting within the media planning workflow.

MPA activates ADIS capabilities when users mention:
- Uploading customer data or transaction files
- Analyzing their customer base
- Creating audiences or segments from their data
- RFM analysis or customer value scoring
- Audience-based media planning
- Optimizing budgets by customer segment
- Customer lifetime value calculations
- Behavioral clustering or propensity modeling

ADIS accepts the following file types for customer data ingestion:
- Excel files with extensions xlsx and xls
- CSV files with comma or tab delimiters
- Word documents containing data tables
- PDF documents containing structured tables
- PowerPoint files containing data tables

Maximum file size is 250MB per upload which aligns with SharePoint limits.

- Customer identifier column with unique customer IDs
- Transaction date column showing when purchases occurred
- Monetary value column showing transaction amounts
sectionTitle: DATA REQUIREMENTS FOR ANALYSIS MINIMUM DATA FOR RFM ANALYSIS

content:
- Email addresses enable platform audience matching
- Phone numbers enable direct channel targeting
- Geographic data enables regional analysis
- Product categories enable behavioral clustering
- Engagement metrics enable propensity scoring

Recency Frequency Monetary analysis creates quintile-based scoring where each customer receives scores from 1 to 5 on three dimensions. Combined scores map to named segments including Champions, Loyal Customers, Potential Loyalists, New Customers, Promising, Customers Needing Attention, About To Sleep, At Risk, Cannot Lose Them, Hibernating, and Lost.

Value-based stratification divides customers into ten equal groups by total monetary value. Decile 10 contains highest-value customers while Decile 1 contains lowest-value customers. Analysis reveals Pareto concentration showing what percentage of value comes from top customer tiers.

Groups customers by first purchase period to measure retention over time. Creates retention matrices showing what percentage of each cohort remains active in subsequent periods. Enables vintage analysis comparing cohort quality across acquisition periods.

Calculates Customer Lifetime Value using historical averages. Formula multiplies Average Order Value by Purchase Frequency by Expected Lifespan by Margin. Provides point estimates without confidence intervals.

Uses BG/NBD and Gamma-Gamma models from the lifetimes library to predict future purchase behavior and monetary value. Accounts for customer dropout probability. Provides uncertainty estimates through prediction intervals.

K-Means clustering groups customers by behavioral similarity across multiple dimensions. Automatically identifies optimal cluster count or accepts user specification. Outputs cluster assignments with distance-to-centroid scores indicating cluster membership strength.

Predicts likelihood of specific customer actions including purchase, churn, or response to campaign. Uses XGBoost classifier trained on historical conversion patterns. Outputs probability scores between 0 and 1 for targeting prioritization.

STEP ONE - DATA UPLOAD
User uploads customer data file through Copilot conversation. System confirms receipt and initiates parsing.

STEP TWO - SCHEMA DETECTION
System automatically detects column types including customer identifiers, dates, monetary values, categories, and contact information. User confirms or corrects detected schema.

STEP THREE - MODEL SELECTION
Based on available data columns, system recommends appropriate analysis models. User selects models to run or accepts recommendations.

STEP FOUR - ANALYSIS EXECUTION
System runs selected models and returns segment distributions with summary statistics. User reviews results and segment composition.

STEP FIVE - AUDIENCE DEFINITION
User defines target audience by selecting segments, applying filters, or combining rules. System calculates audience size and value.

STEP SIX - CHANNEL RECOMMENDATION
System provides channel recommendations based on audience characteristics and segment affinity scores. Recommendations include rationale tied to segment behavior patterns.

STEP SEVEN - CAMPAIGN LINKAGE
User links audience to current media planning session. System stores association for performance tracking and future learning.

AMMO INTEGRATION - AUDIENCE-AWARE MEDIA MIX OPTIMIZATION

AMMO connects ADIS audience segments to budget allocation decisions through channel affinity scoring.

Each audience segment has effectiveness indices by channel. Index values above 1.0 indicate above-average expected response while values below 1.0 indicate below-average expected response.

Champions respond best to Email at 1.4x, Direct Mail at 1.5x, and CTV at 1.3x while responding below average to Linear TV at 0.8x and OOH at 0.7x.

At Risk customers respond best to Email at 1.5x and Direct Mail at 1.4x for retention campaigns while responding poorly to Paid Search at 0.8x.

New Customers respond best to Paid Social at 1.4x and Paid Search at 1.3x for acquisition while Direct Mail shows below-average response at 0.8x.

AMMO runs constrained optimization across the audience by channel matrix to maximize expected response given budget constraints. Optimization accounts for diminishing returns through adstock decay parameters by channel.
System generates Conservative, Moderate, and Aggressive budget scenarios with expected outcomes for each. Calculates marginal returns between scenarios to identify optimal investment level.

When user has existing media plan, AMMO calculates expected lift from optimized allocation versus current allocation. Quantifies revenue and conversion improvement potential.

SEGMENT-TO-CHANNEL GUIDANCE

Prioritize personalized channels including Email, Loyalty Program communications, Premium Display, and Direct Mail. Avoid mass broadcast messaging. Focus messaging on exclusive offers and recognition.
Nurture with consistent multi-channel presence across Email, Social Media, Retargeting, and Paid Search. Message focus on relationship building and program enrollment.
Emphasize Welcome Email sequences, Onboarding content, and Social Media engagement. Avoid aggressive upsell messaging in first 90 days. Focus on education and value demonstration.
Deploy Win-back Email campaigns, Special Offers, and high-touch Retargeting. For Cannot Lose Them segment add Direct Mail and Phone outreach. Avoid generic broadcast communication.
sectionTitle: AT RISK AND CANNOT LOSE THEM

content: Minimize spend on Lost segment which shows below-average response across all channels. Apply occasional low-cost win-back attempts only. Hibernating segment warrants moderate reactivation investment through Email and Discount Offers.
After campaign execution, user can import actual performance data by audience and channel. System calculates actual versus expected variance.
Performance data feeds back into affinity score adjustments. Historical performance overweights base affinity scores for future optimization.
System tracks which audiences were used in which campaigns with attributed results. Enables audience ROI reporting over time.

ADIS integrates with the standard 10-step media planning workflow at multiple points:

STEP 2 TARGET AUDIENCE
When user uploads customer data, ADIS segments inform target audience definition with specific segment recommendations rather than generic demographics.

STEP 4 CHANNEL MIX
Channel affinity scores from AMMO provide data-driven channel recommendations based on actual audience composition rather than industry averages.

STEP 5 BUDGET ALLOCATION
AMMO optimization allocates budget across channels with audience-aware efficiency rather than uniform distribution.

STEP 9 MEASUREMENT PLAN
Performance attribution framework defines what success metrics to track by audience segment.
Full PII storage enabled for development and testing. Customer data stored in Dataverse with access controls.
sectionTitle: DATA PRIVACY AND PII HANDLING PERSONAL ENVIRONMENT

content: PII must be hashed using SHA-256 before storage. No raw email addresses, phone numbers, or identifying information stored in Dataverse. Hash-based matching supports platform audience exports.
When exporting audiences for activation, system supports hashed formats required by Google Ads Customer Match, Meta Custom Audiences, and The Trade Desk.
If file cannot be parsed, system returns specific error message identifying the issue. Common issues include password-protected files, corrupted formats, and unsupported encodings.
If uploaded data lacks minimum required columns for analysis, system identifies missing elements and suggests alternatives.
If analytical model fails to converge or produces invalid results, system falls back to simpler methods and notifies user of limitations.

ADIS uses the following Dataverse tables prefixed with mpa:
- mpa_upload_job tracks file processing status
- mpa_data_schema stores detected column types
- mpa_customer_record stores normalized customer data
- mpa_model_run tracks analysis executions
- mpa_model_output stores per-customer results
- mpa_audience defines named audience segments
- mpa_audience_rule stores filtering criteria
- mpa_audience_member maps customers to audiences
- mpa_campaign_audience links audiences to media plans
- mpa_performance_linkage stores actual campaign results
- mpa_model_catalog lists available analysis models

EXAMPLE ONE - BASIC RFM REQUEST

User: I have a spreadsheet with our customer transaction history. Can you analyze it to help with our media plan?

Agent: Absolutely. Please upload your customer transaction file and I will analyze it to create audience segments that inform your media planning decisions.

Once I receive your file, I will detect the data structure automatically and recommend appropriate analysis models based on the columns available. RFM analysis works best when your data includes customer IDs, transaction dates, and purchase amounts.

What file format is your data in?

EXAMPLE TWO - AUDIENCE-BASED OPTIMIZATION

User: Based on the RFM analysis, which customers should we prioritize for our holiday campaign?

Agent: For a holiday campaign, I recommend prioritizing three audience segments from your RFM results:

Champions representing 12 percent of customers but 34 percent of revenue - these customers respond best to Email and Direct Mail with exclusive early access offers.

Potential Loyalists representing 18 percent of customers showing strong recent engagement - target through Paid Social and Retargeting to convert them to Champions during the holiday period.

At Risk representing 8 percent of customers who were previously high-value - deploy win-back messaging through Email and personalized offers before they fully lapse.

Would you like me to run AMMO optimization to allocate your holiday budget across channels based on these audience segments?

EXAMPLE THREE - AMMO SCENARIO COMPARISON

User: Show me how different budget levels would perform for this audience mix.

allocate your holiday budget across channels based on these audience segments?

EXAMPLE THREE - AMMO SCENARIO COMPARISON

User: Show me how different budget levels would perform for this audience mix.

Agent: I will run three budget scenarios through AMMO optimization for your audience composition:

Conservative scenario at $70,000 total budget projects $182,000 expected revenue with 160 percent ROI. Budget concentrates on highest-efficiency channels including Email and Retargeting.

Moderate scenario at $100,000 total budget projects $245,000 expected revenue with 145 percent ROI. Adds Paid Social and Programmatic Display to expand reach.

Aggressive scenario at $130,000 total budget projects $298,000 expected revenue with 129 percent ROI. Extends into CTV and broader programmatic for awareness.

Marginal returns analysis shows the investment from Conservative to Moderate yields 210 percent return on the additional $30,000. The investment from Moderate to Aggressive yields 177 percent return on the additional $30,000.

My recommendation is the Moderate scenario which balances strong ROI with meaningful revenue growth. Would you like to see the detailed channel allocation for this scenario?

This document provides technical specifications for all analytical models available within the Audience Data Intelligence System. Users must understand model requirements capabilities and limitations before initiating analysis.
Traditional segmentation based on customer purchasing behavior patterns.
Native pandas implementation with numpy for calculations.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- transaction_date representing date of each transaction
- monetary_value representing transaction amount

- transaction_id for deduplication validation
- product_category for category-specific RFM variants

- customer_key matching input identifier
- recency_days representing days since last transaction
- frequency representing total transaction count
- monetary representing total transaction value
- r_score representing recency quintile from 1 to 5
- f_score representing frequency quintile from 1 to 5
- m_score representing monetary quintile from 1 to 5
- rfm_combined representing concatenated three-digit score
- segment_name representing named segment classification
- percentile representing overall customer ranking
100 customers with at least 500 total transactions recommended for reliable quintile boundaries.

Champions receive scores of 5 across all dimensions indicating most recent most frequent highest spending customers.

Loyal Customers show strong frequency and monetary scores with good recency indicating consistent valuable customers.

Potential Loyalists demonstrate recent activity with emerging frequency patterns indicating growth opportunity.

New Customers show very recent first purchases requiring onboarding and development focus.

At Risk customers previously performed well but recency scores indicate declining engagement.

Cannot Lose Them customers show high monetary value but declining recency requiring intervention.

Hibernating customers show low recency with moderate historical value indicating dormancy.

Lost customers show low scores across all dimensions indicating minimal current value.
Value-based customer stratification into ten equal-sized groups.
Native pandas implementation with scipy for statistical calculations.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- value_metric representing the measure for ranking such as revenue or LTV

- transaction_count for supplementary analysis
- customer_tenure for context

- customer_key matching input identifier
- monetary representing aggregated value
- decile representing group assignment from 1 to 10
- percentile representing precise ranking from 1 to 100
- segment_code formatted as D01 through D10
- segment_name formatted as Decile 1 through Decile 10
50 customers minimum for meaningful decile distribution.

Pareto ratio indicates percentage of total value held by top two deciles.

Gini coefficient measures inequality in value distribution from 0 representing perfect equality to 1 representing maximum inequality.
Temporal segmentation tracking customer groups over time.
Native pandas implementation with datetime manipulation.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- transaction_date representing activity timestamps

- monetary_value for value-weighted retention analysis
- activity_type for multi-event cohort tracking

- customer_key matching input identifier
- cohort representing acquisition period designation
- segment_code representing cohort identifier
- segment_name representing formatted cohort label
- cohort_period accepting M for monthly W for weekly or Q for quarterly grouping
200 customers spanning at least three cohort periods for meaningful retention patterns.

Retention matrix shows percentage of each cohort remaining active in subsequent periods.

Average retention by period aggregates across cohorts for trend identification.
Rule-based customer lifetime value calculation using historical averages.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- transaction_date representing purchase timestamps
- monetary_value representing transaction amounts

- margin representing profit margin percentage defaulting to 0.30
- lifespan_years representing projected customer lifespan defaulting to 3 years

- customer_key matching input identifier
- predicted_ltv representing projected lifetime value
- predicted_ltv_lower representing 80 percent lower bound
- predicted_ltv_upper representing 120 percent upper bound
- frequency representing total transaction count
- monetary representing total historical spend
- avg_order_value representing mean transaction amount
- tenure_years representing customer relationship duration
- decile representing LTV-based ranking
100 customers with transaction history spanning at least 90 days.

CLV equals Average Order Value multiplied by Annual Purchase Frequency multiplied by Lifespan Years multiplied by Margin Percentage.

PROBABILISTIC CLV MODEL BG-NBD
Statistical model predicting customer value with uncertainty quantification.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- transaction_date representing purchase timestamps
- monetary_value representing transaction amounts
- prediction_period representing days to forecast defaulting to 365

- customer_key matching input identifier
- predicted_ltv representing expected lifetime value
- predicted_purchases representing expected transaction count
- prob_alive representing probability customer is still active
- frequency representing historical transaction count
- recency representing days since first to last transaction
- T representing days since first transaction to analysis date
- monetary representing average transaction value
500 customers with transaction history spanning at least 180 days for reliable model fitting.

BG-NBD parameters including r alpha a and b describing population-level purchasing patterns.

Gamma-Gamma parameters describing monetary value distribution.

Model assumes stationary purchasing process which may not hold during promotions or seasonality.

Model requires repeat purchasers meaning customers with only one transaction receive limited predictions.
Library is pre-approved for Mastercard environment.
Unsupervised learning discovering natural customer groupings.
- At minimum two numeric columns for clustering dimensions

- customer_key for customer-level cluster assignment
- Additional numeric features improve cluster differentiation

- n_clusters representing desired cluster count defaulting to 5
- feature_columns representing list of columns to use for clustering

- customer_key if provided in input
- cluster_id representing assigned cluster from 0 to n_clusters minus 1
- cluster_distance representing distance to assigned cluster centroid
- segment_code formatted as C00 through Cnn
- segment_name formatted as Cluster 0 through Cluster n
500 records minimum for reliable clustering. 1000 or more recommended.

Silhouette score measuring cluster cohesion and separation from negative 1 to 1 where higher is better.

Inertia representing within-cluster sum of squares where lower indicates tighter clusters.

Cluster centroids showing mean feature values for each cluster.

K-Means assumes spherical clusters which may not represent all natural groupings.

Cluster count must be specified or determined through experimentation.

Outliers significantly influence centroid positions.
Library is pre-approved for Mastercard environment.
Supervised learning predicting likelihood of target behavior.
scikit-learn for basic models or xgboost version 1.7.0 or higher for gradient boosting.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- target_variable representing binary outcome to predict
- At minimum three feature columns for model training

- customer_key matching input identifier
- propensity_score representing predicted probability from 0 to 1
- decile representing propensity-based ranking
- segment_code formatted by propensity tier
- segment_name describing propensity level
1000 records minimum with at least 100 positive outcomes for reliable model training.

AUC-ROC measuring discrimination ability from 0.5 representing random to 1.0 representing perfect.

Precision and recall at various thresholds.

Feature importance rankings.
XGBoost requires approval verification. Scikit-learn alternatives are pre-approved.
Causal inference identifying customers most responsive to treatment.

- customer_key representing unique customer identifier
- treatment representing binary treatment indicator
- outcome representing measured response variable
- At minimum three feature columns for heterogeneity modeling

- customer_key matching input identifier
- uplift_score representing estimated treatment effect
- decile representing uplift-based ranking
- segment_code formatted by uplift tier
- segment_name describing uplift level
5000 records minimum with balanced treatment and control groups.

AUUC representing area under uplift curve.

Qini coefficient measuring targeting effectiveness.

Requires valid randomized treatment assignment.

Observational data requires strong assumptions for causal interpretation.
CausalML requires approval verification before use.

Pre-approved models include:

- RFM
- Decile
- Cohort
- Deterministic CLV
- Probabilistic CLV via lifetimes
- K-Means Clustering

Models requiring approval verification include:

- Propensity via XGBoost
- Uplift via CausalML

For customer understanding start with RFM to establish behavioral segments.

For value analysis use Decile to understand concentration and Deterministic CLV for projections.

For retention focus use Cohort analysis to identify lifecycle patterns.

For sophisticated projections use Probabilistic CLV when data requirements are met.

For behavioral discovery use K-Means when segments should emerge from data patterns.

For targeting optimization use Propensity models when labeled outcomes are available.

For treatment allocation use Uplift models when understanding incremental impact is critical.

This document provides rapid reference for ADIS (Audience Data Intelligence System) capabilities. ADIS analyzes customer data files to create actionable segments for media planning. Use this reference to determine which model to recommend and how to integrate results into planning steps.

Offer ADIS analysis when user mentions ANY of these:
- Customer data or transaction data
- CRM exports or customer files
- Segmentation or segments
- RFM or recency frequency monetary
- CLV or lifetime value or LTV
- Best customers or high-value customers
- Retention or churn
- Customer clusters or groupings
- Propensity or likelihood
- Uplift or incrementality
I can analyze your customer data to identify segments and optimize targeting. Upload your file to get started. I support Excel, CSV, and text formats.

EIGHT MODELS are available. Select based on user need:

MODEL 1 RFM SEGMENTATION

WHEN TO USE: User wants to understand customer behavior patterns and segment by engagement level.

WHAT IT DOES: Scores customers on recency, frequency, and monetary value. Creates named segments.

KEY SEGMENTS CREATED:
- Champions: Best customers across all dimensions
- Loyal Customers: Consistent high value
- Potential Loyalists: Recent with emerging frequency
- New Customers: Very recent first purchases
- At Risk: Previously good, now declining
- Cannot Lose Them: High value but declining recency
- Hibernating: Dormant with moderate history
- Lost: Low across all dimensions

MINIMUM DATA: 100 customers, 500 transactions

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, transaction_date, monetary_value

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Champions: Upsell, loyalty programs, referral campaigns
- At Risk: Retargeting, win-back offers, email reengagement
- New Customers: Onboarding sequences, second purchase incentives
- Lost: Exclude from acquisition spend, deep discount reactivation only

MODEL 2 DECILE ANALYSIS

WHEN TO USE: User wants to understand value concentration and identify top versus bottom customer tiers.

WHAT IT DOES: Ranks customers into ten equal groups by value. Shows Pareto ratio and Gini coefficient.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Decile 1: Top 10% by value
- Decile 10: Bottom 10% by value
- Pareto ratio: Percentage of value from top 20%
- Gini coefficient: Inequality measure 0 to 1

MINIMUM DATA: 50 customers

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, value_metric

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Budget allocation: Weight spend toward deciles with best ROI potential
- Audience sizing: Use decile distribution to estimate addressable value
- Exclusions: Consider excluding bottom deciles from acquisition campaigns

Weight spend toward deciles with best ROI potential
- Audience sizing: Use decile distribution to estimate addressable value
- Exclusions: Consider excluding bottom deciles from acquisition campaigns

MODEL 3 COHORT ANALYSIS

WHEN TO USE: User wants to understand retention patterns and how customer groups perform over time.

WHAT IT DOES: Groups customers by acquisition period and tracks activity in subsequent periods.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Retention matrix by cohort
- Average retention by period
- Cohort-over-cohort trends

MINIMUM DATA: 200 customers across 3+ periods

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, transaction_date

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Budget timing: Invest more during high-retention cohort periods
- Channel evaluation: Compare retention by acquisition channel
- Lifecycle targeting: Adjust messaging by cohort maturity

MODEL 4 DETERMINISTIC CLV

WHEN TO USE: User wants straightforward lifetime value estimates using historical averages.

WHAT IT DOES: Calculates CLV using average order value, purchase frequency, lifespan, and margin.

FORMULA: CLV = AOV x Annual Frequency x Lifespan Years x Margin

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Predicted LTV with upper and lower bounds
- AOV and frequency metrics
- Customer tenure
- LTV-based decile ranking

MINIMUM DATA: 100 customers, 90 days history

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, transaction_date, monetary_value

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- CAC ceiling: Set acquisition cost targets based on LTV
- Budget justification: Show LTV to CAC ratio to stakeholders
- Segment prioritization: Focus on segments with highest LTV

MODEL 5 PROBABILISTIC CLV

ceiling: Set acquisition cost targets based on LTV
- Budget justification: Show LTV to CAC ratio to stakeholders
- Segment prioritization: Focus on segments with highest LTV

MODEL 5 PROBABILISTIC CLV

WHEN TO USE: User wants sophisticated LTV predictions with uncertainty quantification and probability customer is still active.

WHAT IT DOES: Uses BG-NBD statistical model to predict future purchases and value with confidence intervals.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Predicted LTV with statistical confidence
- Predicted purchase count
- Probability alive score
- BG-NBD model parameters

MINIMUM DATA: 500 customers, 180 days history

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, transaction_date, monetary_value

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Reactivation targeting: Focus on customers with low prob_alive but high historical value
- Budget forecasting: Use predicted purchases for revenue modeling
- Risk assessment: Identify customers likely to churn

MODEL 6 K-MEANS CLUSTERING

WHEN TO USE: User wants to discover natural customer groupings without predefined segment definitions.

WHAT IT DOES: Uses unsupervised machine learning to find clusters based on multiple features.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Cluster assignments with distance scores
- Cluster centroids showing average feature values
- Silhouette score measuring cluster quality
- Inertia measuring cluster tightness

MINIMUM DATA: 500 records, 1000+ recommended

REQUIRED COLUMNS: At minimum two numeric feature columns

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Audience discovery: Find segments you did not know existed
- Creative development: Tailor messaging to cluster characteristics
- Channel affinity: Analyze which channels each cluster prefers

CATION:
- Audience discovery: Find segments you did not know existed
- Creative development: Tailor messaging to cluster characteristics
- Channel affinity: Analyze which channels each cluster prefers

MODEL 7 PROPENSITY MODEL

WHEN TO USE: User has labeled outcomes and wants to predict likelihood of specific customer behaviors.

WHAT IT DOES: Trains supervised model to predict probability of target action like purchase, churn, or upgrade.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Propensity score 0 to 1 for each customer
- Propensity-based deciles
- AUC-ROC model performance
- Feature importance rankings

MINIMUM DATA: 1000 records, 100+ positive outcomes

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, target_variable, 3+ feature columns

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Targeting precision: Focus media on high-propensity customers
- Lookalike modeling: Use high-propensity customers as seed audience
- Budget efficiency: Exclude low-propensity customers from expensive channels

MODEL 8 UPLIFT MODEL

WHEN TO USE: User needs to identify customers most responsive to specific treatments or offers rather than just most likely to convert.

WHAT IT DOES: Uses causal inference to estimate incremental treatment effect for each customer.

KEY OUTPUTS:
- Uplift score per customer
- Uplift-based deciles
- AUUC performance metric
- Qini coefficient

MINIMUM DATA: 5000 records with balanced treatment and control

REQUIRED COLUMNS: customer_key, treatment indicator, outcome, 3+ feature columns

MEDIA PLANNING APPLICATION:
- Incrementality optimization: Target customers where media drives incremental response
- Holdout design: Identify optimal treatment and control allocation
- Budget efficiency: Avoid spending on customers who would convert anyway

: Target customers where media drives incremental response
- Holdout design: Identify optimal treatment and control allocation
- Budget efficiency: Avoid spending on customers who would convert anyway

STEP-BY-STEP ADIS INTEGRATION

STEP 3-4 AUDIENCE

Ask: Do you have customer transaction data? I can run RFM segmentation to identify your Champions, Loyal Customers, and At Risk segments, then recommend channels optimized for each group.

If user uploads data, run RFM first. Then offer additional models:
- For value concentration: Also run Decile analysis
- For retention patterns: Also run Cohort analysis
- For discovering new segments: Also run K-Means clustering

STEP 5 BUDGET

With ADIS segments available, offer AMMO optimization:

Based on your segment analysis, I can optimize budget allocation across Champions, At Risk, and New Customer segments using channel affinity data. Champions typically respond best to email and loyalty programs. At Risk customers need retargeting investment. Want me to build the segment-level budget allocation?

STEP 7 CHANNELS

Reference ADIS segment affinities in channel recommendations:

Based on your ADIS analysis:
- Champions: Email, direct mail, loyalty programs
- Loyal Customers: Email, social, content marketing
- At Risk: Retargeting, email win-back, limited paid acquisition
- New Customers: Onboarding email, social proof, review requests
- High Propensity: Premium channels, personalized offers
- High Uplift: Treatment-focused campaigns, A/B test priority

SUPPORTED FORMATS: Excel (.xlsx, .xls), CSV (.csv), tab-delimited text

REQUIRED FOR ALL MODELS:
- customer_key or customer_id or similar unique identifier
- Clean headers in first row
- No merged cells
- Consistent date formats

SIZE LIMITS: Up to 250MB file size

COMMON ISSUES:
- Missing customer identifier: Cannot run analysis
- Mixed date formats: May cause parsing errors
- Special characters in headers: May cause column mapping issues

If file upload fails, suggest:
- Check file format is Excel or CSV
- Ensure first row contains column headers
- Remove merged cells or special formatting
- Verify file is under 250MB

If model requirements not met, explain:
- Which columns are missing
- Minimum record count needed
- Suggest alternative model if data is insufficient

For detailed model specifications: See ADIS_Model_Catalog_v1
For user-facing documentation: See ADIS_User_Guide_v1
For step-specific integration: See ADIS_Copilot_Integration_v2
For core operating standards: See KB_00_Agent_Core_Operating_Standards_v6_6

The Audience Data Intelligence System enables users to upload customer data files and transform them into actionable audience segments for media planning. ADIS analyzes transaction histories, engagement metrics, loyalty data, and CRM exports to create intelligent audience definitions that inform channel selection and budget allocation.

Users must understand that ADIS operates within their existing media planning workflow. The system does not replace strategic thinking but rather enhances it with data-driven audience insights.

ADIS accepts the following file formats for customer data ingestion:

- Excel files including xlsx and xls formats with single or multiple sheets
- CSV files with standard comma or semicolon delimiters
- Word documents containing embedded data tables
- PDF documents with extractable tabular content
- PowerPoint files with data tables in slides

Maximum file size is 250 megabytes which aligns with SharePoint limits. Files exceeding this threshold must be split before upload.

Users must ensure uploaded files contain at minimum a customer identifier column and at least one behavioral or transactional column. Files without identifiable customer keys cannot be processed for audience segmentation.

RFM analysis requires three specific data elements:

- Customer identifier allowing unique customer recognition across transactions
- Transaction date indicating when each purchase or engagement occurred
- Monetary value representing the financial amount of each transaction

The system automatically detects these columns based on naming patterns and data characteristics. Confidence scores indicate detection reliability.
sectionTitle: DATA REQUIREMENTS BY ANALYSIS TYPE RFM ANALYSIS REQUIREMENTS

content:
Decile analysis requires:

- Customer identifier for grouping transactions by customer
- Value metric such as revenue or lifetime value for ranking

Cohort analysis requires:

- Customer identifier for tracking individual customers over time
- Transaction or engagement dates for determining cohort membership and activity periods

Customer Lifetime Value analysis requires:

- Customer identifier for individual customer tracking
- Transaction dates for calculating recency and frequency
- Monetary values for determining average order value and total spend

Probabilistic CLV models additionally benefit from longer transaction histories spanning at least six months.

Behavioral clustering requires:

- At minimum two numeric attributes for meaningful cluster differentiation
- Customer identifier if customer-level clusters are desired
- Larger datasets of at least 500 records produce more reliable clusters

Upon file upload ADIS automatically analyzes column contents to infer semantic types. The system examines:

- Column names for pattern matching against known field types
- Sample values for format detection including email patterns phone formats and date structures
- Statistical characteristics including uniqueness ratios and null percentages
- Data distributions to identify categorical versus continuous variables

Detected types include:

- CUSTOMER_ID for unique customer identifiers
- TRANSACTION_ID for unique transaction identifiers
- EMAIL for electronic mail addresses
- PHONE for telephone numbers
- DATE for temporal values
- CURRENCY for monetary amounts
- CATEGORY for categorical classifications
- NUMERIC for continuous numeric values
- TEXT for free-form text content
- ENGAGEMENT_SCORE for behavioral scoring metrics
- LOYALTY_TIER for membership level classifications

Users must verify detected schemas before proceeding with analysis. Override capability exists for correcting misidentified column types.
ADIS provides multiple analytical models. Selection depends on business objectives and data availability.

Use RFM analysis when the goal is customer segmentation based on purchasing behavior. RFM produces segments including:

- Champions representing highest value most frequent most recent customers
- Loyal Customers representing consistent purchasers with strong engagement
- Potential Loyalists representing recent customers showing promise for development
- New Customers representing recent first-time purchasers
- At Risk representing previously good customers showing decline
- Cannot Lose Them representing high-value customers at risk of churn
- Hibernating representing inactive customers with some historical value
- Lost representing long-inactive low-value customers

Each customer receives scores from 1 to 5 for Recency Frequency and Monetary dimensions. Combined scores map to named segments.

Use Decile analysis when the goal is value-based stratification. This model divides customers into ten equal-sized groups ranked by a chosen value metric. Results reveal value concentration patterns including what percentage of value the top decile represents.

Use Cohort analysis when the goal is understanding retention patterns over time. This model groups customers by their acquisition period and tracks subsequent activity. Results include retention matrices showing percentage of each cohort remaining active in subsequent periods.

Use deterministic CLV when transaction history is limited or when simple projections suffice. The model applies average order value multiplied by purchase frequency multiplied by estimated lifespan multiplied by margin.

Use probabilistic CLV via BG-NBD model when transaction history spans at least six months and when statistical rigor is required. This model accounts for customer dropout probability and produces confidence intervals around predictions.

Use K-Means clustering when the goal is discovering behavioral segments without predefined categories. The model groups customers based on multiple numeric attributes. Users specify desired cluster count or allow automatic selection based on optimization metrics.

After analysis completes users create audiences by selecting model outputs and optionally applying filtering rules.

RULE-BASED FILTERING

Rules support the following operators:

- EQUALS for exact match filtering
- NOT_EQUALS for exclusion filtering
- GREATER_THAN and GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL for numeric thresholds
- LESS_THAN and LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL for numeric ceilings
- IN and NOT_IN for list-based inclusion or exclusion
- BETWEEN for range filtering
- CONTAINS for substring matching
- IS_NULL and IS_NOT_NULL for presence filtering

Rules combine using AND or OR logic with grouping support for complex expressions.

The system automatically generates:

- Recommended channels based on segment characteristics and historical affinity patterns
- Suggested use cases identifying appropriate campaign types for the audience
- Value concentration metrics showing revenue distribution across members

Users should treat recommendations as starting points requiring strategic validation rather than prescriptive directives.
The Audience-Aware Media Mix Optimization framework connects audiences to budget allocation decisions.

AMMO maintains channel effectiveness indices by audience segment. Champions typically show elevated response to Email Direct Mail and Premium Display. At Risk segments respond better to personalized retargeting and win-back messaging than to broad reach channels.

Users provide:

- Total budget for the campaign
- Audiences to target
- Channels under consideration
- Any channel-specific constraints including minimums and maximums
- Optimization objective selecting from ROI Revenue or Conversions

AMMO produces:

- Optimal budget allocation percentages by channel
- Expected impressions conversions and revenue by channel
- Expected ROI for the recommended allocation
- Comparison against current allocation if provided showing expected lift
Users can run multiple budget scenarios to understand marginal returns. Conservative moderate and aggressive scenarios reveal diminishing return patterns and inform budget negotiation.
After campaign execution users import actual performance data to close the measurement loop.

Performance data must include:

- Audience or campaign identifier for matching
- Channel identification
- Measurement date
- Actual metrics including spend impressions clicks conversions and revenue

The system calculates:

- Variance between expected and actual performance by audience and channel
- Updated affinity scores based on observed results
- Recommendations for future targeting based on performance patterns
The Aragorn AI environment provides full ADIS capabilities including all analytical models web search for benchmark enrichment and unrestricted Azure Function execution.

The Mastercard corporate environment operates with specific constraints:

- No external API access requiring all benchmarks to be pre-loaded
- PII handling requires hashing or masking before storage
- Only pre-approved Python libraries available in Azure Functions
- All data remains within managed tenant boundaries

Users must ensure uploaded data complies with corporate data handling policies before initiating analysis.

- Clean data before upload removing duplicate transactions and correcting obvious errors
- Ensure consistent date formats across transaction records
- Verify customer identifiers are truly unique and consistent over time
- Include sufficient transaction history spanning at least three months for meaningful RFM analysis

- Start with RFM for initial customer understanding when transaction data is available
- Use Decile analysis when comparing value tiers against marketing investment
- Apply Cohort analysis when retention questions drive the investigation
- Reserve probabilistic CLV for mature datasets with extended history

- Create audiences with clear use cases rather than generic segments
- Size audiences appropriately for intended channels considering minimum match requirements
- Document audience logic for future reference and reproducibility
- Version audiences when updating to maintain historical comparability

- Validate AMMO recommendations against strategic intent before adoption
- Use scenario analysis to understand budget sensitivity
- Compare optimized allocations to current plans to quantify improvement opportunity
- Update affinity matrices with actual performance to improve future recommendations

- Verify file is not password protected or corrupted
- Ensure file size is within 250 megabyte limit
- Check that file contains actual data rows not just headers
- Confirm file format matches extension

- Manually override detected types when automatic inference fails
- Ensure columns have consistent data within each column
- Remove merged cells or complex formatting from Excel files

- Verify required columns are present and correctly mapped
- Ensure minimum record counts are met for selected model
- Check for excessive null values in required fields

- Verify rule field names match available columns
- Ensure rule values are appropriate for field types
- Check that rule logic produces at least one matching member

For technical issues contact the platform support team through established channels. Provide upload job identifiers model run identifiers and error messages when reporting problems.

For strategic guidance on audience design and optimization application consult with media planning specialists who can contextualize system outputs within broader campaign objectives.

DOCUMENT: AI_ADVERTISING_GUIDE_v5_5.txt
CATEGORY: Guide
TOPICS: AI advertising, machine learning, optimization, creative AI, automated bidding

AI IN ADVERTISING - COMPREHENSIVE GUIDE
VERSION: 5.5
DATE: January 2026
STATUS: Production Ready
COMPLIANCE: 6-Rule Compliant
================================================================================

This document provides guidance on artificial intelligence applications in advertising and media planning. As AI increasingly drives campaign optimization, creative generation, and audience targeting, media planners must understand capabilities, limitations, and oversight requirements. This guide enables informed recommendations on AI-powered advertising approaches while maintaining the incrementality-first philosophy central to MPA.

================================================================================

AI has fundamentally transformed advertising execution and planning:

- 30 percent of marketing messages are AI-generated as of 2025 (Gartner)
- Over 15,000 AI-powered MarTech solutions available
- Major platforms have shifted to AI-first campaign types
- Creative generation, optimization, and measurement increasingly automated
- Transparency and control continue decreasing as AI sophistication increases

Campaign Optimization
- Automated bidding and budget allocation
- Audience expansion and targeting
- Placement optimization across inventory
- Real-time performance adjustments

Creative Generation and Optimization
- Text generation for ad copy
- Image generation for display and social
- Video generation emerging but nascent
- Dynamic creative optimization (DCO)
- Automated creative testing

Audience and Targeting
- Lookalike and similar audience modeling
- Predictive audience segmentation
- Intent signal analysis
- Cross-platform identity resolution

Measurement and Attribution
- Conversion modeling for signal loss
- Incrementality estimation
- Media mix optimization
- Predictive analytics

AI-powered advertising creates tension between efficiency and understanding:

Advantages
- Scale optimization beyond human capacity
- Real-time adjustment to performance signals
- Pattern recognition across large datasets
- Reduced manual optimization labor

Challenges
- Reduced transparency into decision-making
- Limited control over targeting and creative
- Difficulty measuring true incremental impact
- Platform incentives may not align with advertiser goals

================================================================================

Overview
- Meta's AI-powered campaign type consolidating ad sets and audiences
- Reduces manual targeting controls in favor of algorithmic optimization
- Includes Advantage Plus Shopping Campaigns (ASC) and Advantage Plus App Campaigns
- Uses machine learning to optimize across placements, audiences, and creative

How It Works
- Advertiser provides creative assets and conversion objective
- Algorithm determines audience targeting dynamically
- Budget allocated automatically across placements
- Creative combinations tested and optimized algorithmically

Typical Performance Claims
- Meta reports 12 to 20 percent improvement in cost per result versus standard campaigns
- Performance gains vary significantly by vertical and advertiser maturity
- Existing high-performing campaigns may show less improvement
- New advertisers often see larger gains due to learning curve bypass

Planning Considerations
- Limited audience exclusion capabilities (some controls recently added)
- Cannot fully separate prospecting from retargeting budget
- Creative quality becomes primary lever for optimization
- Measurement relies heavily on Meta's conversion modeling

Best Practices
- Provide diverse creative assets for algorithm to test
- Use cost cap bidding to maintain efficiency guardrails
- Monitor for audience overlap with other campaigns
- Validate claimed performance with incrementality testing

Overview
- Google's AI-powered cross-channel campaign type
- Serves across Search, Display, YouTube, Discover, Gmail, and Maps
- Uses Asset Groups containing creative elements optimized by AI
- Replaced Smart Shopping and Local campaigns

How It Works
- Advertiser provides assets (images, videos, text) and conversion goals
- AI generates ad combinations from provided assets
- Algorithm optimizes across Google properties automatically
- Budget and bidding controlled at campaign level

Typical Performance Claims
- Google reports 18 percent average improvement in conversions at similar CPA
- Results vary significantly by vertical and campaign setup
- Search cannibalization common concern
- Performance may plateau as learning stabilizes

Planning Considerations
- Very limited placement and audience transparency
- Difficult to attribute results to specific channels
- May cannibalize branded search traffic
- Creative asset quality directly impacts performance

Best Practices
- Exclude brand keywords through negative keyword lists
- Monitor branded search impression share separately
- Use audience signals as hints rather than targeting
- Maintain parallel standard campaigns for comparison
- Implement incrementality testing before scaling

Overview
- Amazon's programmatic buying with algorithmic optimization
- Includes audiences, contextual, and product targeting
- Automated bidding across Amazon owned and operated plus open web
- Leverages Amazon's first-party purchase data

How It Works
- Advertiser selects campaign objective and targeting parameters
- AI optimizes bids, placements, and audience segments
- Performance Max style automation available for some campaign types
- Amazon Marketing Cloud provides deeper analysis capabilities

Planning Considerations
- Strong first-party data foundation differentiates from other platforms
- Closed-loop measurement advantage for endemic advertisers
- Off-Amazon inventory less transparent than on-platform
- Cost efficiency varies significantly by category and competition

COMMON BLACK-BOX CHALLENGES

Attribution Concerns
- Platforms credit their own touchpoints favorably
- Last-click and modeled attribution may overstate impact
- Cross-platform measurement gaps persist
- Self-reported ROAS often exceeds true incremental value

Control Limitations
- Cannot fully control audience targeting
- Creative rotation not fully transparent
- Budget allocation across placements unclear
- Optimization toward platform inventory, not advertiser efficiency

Transparency Gaps
- Limited reporting on where ads served
- Audience composition often opaque
- Bidding logic not disclosed
- Incremental versus non-incremental traffic unclear

================================================================================

Applications
- Ad headline and description generation
- Email marketing copy
- Product descriptions at scale
- Social media content
- Landing page optimization

Capabilities
- Large language models produce fluent, contextual text
- Can generate multiple variants for testing
- Adapts to brand voice with proper prompting
- Enables personalization at scale

Limitations
- May produce inaccurate or inconsistent claims
- Brand safety requires human review
- Legal and compliance review still necessary
- Quality varies significantly by model and prompting

Best Practices
- Use AI for initial draft generation and variant creation
- Require human review before publication
- Establish brand guidelines and constraints in prompts
- Monitor for factual accuracy and brand consistency
- Test AI-generated copy against human-created for performance

Applications
- Display advertising creative
- Social media imagery
- Product visualization
- Background and lifestyle imagery
- Creative variant generation

Current State
- Quality has improved dramatically but remains inconsistent
- Photorealistic images possible but with artifacts
- Product images often require human refinement
- Brand asset integration still challenging

Limitations
- May produce anatomically incorrect human imagery
- Text rendering often poor
- Brand consistency difficult to maintain
- Copyright and ownership questions unresolved

Best Practices
- Use for iteration and concepting, not final production
- Combine AI generation with human refinement
- Establish clear brand asset guidelines
- Monitor for unintended brand associations
- Consider legal review for commercial use

Applications
- Social media short-form video
- Product demonstration clips
- Animation and motion graphics
- User-generated content style videos

Current State
- Quality improving rapidly but not production-ready for most uses
- Short clips more reliable than long-form
- Animation more reliable than photorealistic
- Audio and voice synthesis maturing

Limitations
- Motion artifacts common
- Lip sync and movement unnatural
- Long-form content remains challenging
- Premium brand quality difficult to achieve

Best Practices
- Appropriate for testing and social content
- Not recommended for TV or high-production campaigns
- Combine AI elements with traditional production
- Establish quality thresholds before use

================================================================================

What DCO Does
- Assembles ads from component parts in real-time
- Selects elements based on user context, behavior, or segment
- Enables personalization at scale without manual creative production
- Optimizes combinations based on performance data

DCO Components
- Templates defining layout and structure
- Dynamic elements (images, text, calls-to-action, pricing)
- Rules or algorithms determining element selection
- Optimization logic improving over time

Research Findings
- DCO campaigns show 58 percent higher ROAS than static creative on average
- Lift varies significantly by implementation quality
- Personalization benefit depends on audience diversity
- Optimization requires sufficient data volume

Performance Drivers
- Relevance of dynamic elements to user context
- Quality of underlying creative assets
- Sophistication of personalization rules
- Data availability for targeting signals

Data Requirements
- First-party data enables strongest personalization
- Product feeds for retail and e-commerce
- Location data for local relevance
- Behavioral signals for intent-based messaging

Technical Requirements
- Creative management platform
- Data feed integration
- Real-time decisioning capability
- Cross-platform measurement

Best Practices
- Start with highest-impact dynamic elements (product, price, location)
- Test DCO against static control for true lift measurement
- Ensure sufficient creative variety for algorithm learning
- Monitor for creative fatigue as combinations exhaust

================================================================================

Platform-reported metrics for AI-powered campaigns often overstate true performance:

- Self-attribution bias credits platform touchpoints
- Modeled conversions may include non-incremental sales
- Audience expansion may reach customers who would have converted anyway
- Reported ROAS typically 2 to 3x higher than incremental ROAS

Incrementality Testing
- Geo-based holdout tests isolate true campaign impact
- Ghost bidding measures baseline without exposure
- PSA testing controls for targeting without message effect
- Required for accurate budget allocation decisions

Recommended Testing Cadence
- Quarterly for ongoing campaigns
- Before scaling any AI-powered campaign
- When making significant budget changes
- After major platform or campaign structure updates

A/B Testing Against Manual Campaigns
- Run parallel standard campaigns for comparison
- Isolate AI-driven improvements from other factors
- Measure incrementality for both approaches
- Consider total cost including management overhead

Cross-Platform Comparison
- Compare platform-reported results across channels
- Use holdout testing to validate each platform
- Identify discrepancies indicating measurement issues
- Apply consistent methodology across platforms

Media Mix Modeling Integration
- Include AI campaign spend in MMM analysis
- Validate MMM coefficients against incrementality tests
- Use MMM for cross-channel budget allocation
- Reconcile differences between approaches

Primary Validation Metrics
- Incremental ROAS (iROAS) - True incremental revenue divided by spend
- Lift percentage - Exposed versus control group performance difference
- Cost per incremental acquisition - Spend divided by true incremental customers

Secondary Validation Metrics
- New-to-brand rate - Indicator of expansion versus retention
- Search brand query volume - Leading indicator of awareness impact
- Cross-channel sales impact - Total business impact beyond direct response

Red Flags Indicating Measurement Issues
- ROAS significantly higher than historical norms
- ROAS inconsistent with business results
- New-to-brand rate suspiciously low
- Claimed performance increases without business result changes

================================================================================

AI-powered advertising requires human oversight across multiple dimensions:

Strategic Oversight
- Campaign objective alignment with business goals
- Budget allocation across AI and manual campaigns
- Platform selection and portfolio balance
- Performance threshold and guardrail definition

Creative Oversight
- Brand safety and consistency review
- Legal and compliance verification
- Factual accuracy checking
- Quality threshold enforcement

Performance Oversight
- Regular validation testing
- Business result reconciliation
- Anomaly detection and investigation
- Course correction when needed

Daily Monitoring
- Pacing and budget consumption
- Major performance anomalies
- Brand safety incidents

Weekly Review
- Performance trends versus targets
- Creative performance analysis
- Audience insights review

Monthly Analysis
- Full performance assessment
- Incrementality checkpoint
- Budget reallocation decisions
- Strategy refinement

Quarterly Validation
- Comprehensive incrementality testing
- MMM refresh with current data
- Platform performance comparison
- Strategic planning updates

Increase Human Control When
- Brand safety concerns arise
- Performance significantly deviates from expectations
- New products or campaigns launching
- Competitive activity requires response
- Seasonal or promotional periods

Indicators AI May Not Be Optimizing Appropriately
- Declining new-to-brand rate suggests over-retargeting
- Geographic concentration in few markets
- Creative rotation favoring low-quality assets
- Conversion quality declining despite volume increasing

================================================================================

When to Use
- Broad audience products with mass appeal
- Sufficient creative assets for algorithm testing
- Conversion volume supports optimization
- Willing to accept reduced targeting control

When to Avoid
- Narrow target audiences
- Brand safety concerns requiring control
- Limited creative assets
- Need for precise budget allocation

Setup Best Practices
- Provide minimum 5 to 10 creative variations
- Use cost caps to maintain efficiency
- Exclude existing customers if acquisition focus
- Monitor audience insights for targeting creep

When to Use
- Cross-channel presence desired
- Sufficient conversion volume (50+ per month)
- Asset library supports diverse ad formats
- Business tolerates limited transparency

When to Avoid
- Need for channel-level optimization
- Brand term performance is critical
- Limited asset availability
- Require detailed placement reporting

Setup Best Practices
- Exclude brand keywords from Performance Max
- Maintain standard search campaigns for brand
- Use audience signals to guide (not control) targeting
- Create asset groups aligned to distinct products or goals

When to Use
- Products sold on Amazon marketplace
- Seeking first-party data advantage
- Closed-loop measurement important
- Both on and off Amazon reach desired

When to Avoid
- Products not sold on Amazon
- Limited budget for meaningful test
- Require detailed off-Amazon transparency
- Non-endemic without strong audience fit

Setup Best Practices
- Separate on-Amazon and off-Amazon for analysis
- Use Amazon Marketing Cloud for deeper insights
- Test sponsored ads before scaling DSP
- Monitor new-to-brand metrics closely

================================================================================

Step 1 - Assess Advertiser Readiness
- Does advertiser have sufficient creative assets
- Is conversion volume adequate for AI optimization
- Can advertiser tolerate reduced control
- Is measurement infrastructure in place for validation

Step 2 - Select Appropriate AI Campaign Types
- Match campaign type to business objective
- Consider platform strengths and advertiser presence
- Evaluate transparency requirements
- Assess budget adequacy for meaningful test

Step 3 - Establish Validation Plan
- Define incrementality testing approach
- Set validation timeline and cadence
- Identify comparison benchmarks
- Plan for result interpretation

Step 4 - Define Guardrails and Limits
- Set efficiency thresholds (target CPA, ROAS floors)
- Establish brand safety requirements
- Define audience and placement exclusions
- Determine budget caps for testing phase

Step 5 - Plan Oversight and Iteration
- Assign monitoring responsibilities
- Define intervention triggers
- Plan optimization cadence
- Schedule validation tests

Test Phase (1-3 months)
- Allocate 10 to 20 percent of channel budget to AI campaigns
- Run parallel with standard campaigns for comparison
- Focus on learning rather than efficiency
- Plan for incrementality test at end of period

Scale Phase (after validation)
- Increase allocation based on validated incremental performance
- Never allocate 100 percent to black-box campaigns
- Maintain manual campaigns for control and comparison
- Revalidate incrementality periodically

Portfolio Approach
- Diversify across AI and manual campaigns
- Use AI for broad reach and manual for precision
- Maintain ability to diagnose performance issues
- Ensure some transparent campaigns for learning

================================================================================

AI Agents in Advertising
- Autonomous systems managing campaigns end-to-end
- Reduced human touchpoints in optimization
- Strategic planning assistance from AI
- Implications for agency and advertiser roles

Multimodal AI
- Combined text, image, and video generation
- Integrated creative production workflows
- Personalization across formats
- Quality improvements enabling broader use

Privacy-Preserving AI
- On-device machine learning for targeting
- Federated learning across platforms
- Differential privacy in measurement
- Reduced signal without reduced capability

Regulation and Transparency Requirements
- AI disclosure requirements emerging
- Political advertising restrictions
- Consumer protection considerations
- Platform accountability requirements

Use web search to obtain current information when:

- Specific platform feature updates needed
- Recent AI capability announcements requested
- Regulatory developments require verification
- Benchmark data needs updating

================================================================================
sectionTitle: KNOWLEDGE GAPS AND WEB SEARCH TRIGGERS

content:
When specific AI campaign functionality is unknown:

- Recommend checking platform documentation for current features
- Suggest conservative testing approach
- Emphasize validation regardless of claimed capabilities
- Reference general AI campaign principles
sectionTitle: IF AI CAMPAIGN CAPABILITIES ARE UNCLEAR

content:
When category or platform-specific benchmarks are not available:

- Use general platform benchmarks as starting point
- Recommend establishing baselines through testing
- Emphasize relative performance versus absolute targets
- Suggest incrementality testing to establish true baseline

When best validation method is uncertain:

- Default to geo-based holdout testing as most robust
- Recommend sufficient test duration (minimum 4 weeks)
- Suggest statistical significance validation
- Plan for result interpretation before testing

================================================================================

- Analytics Engine v5.1 - Incrementality testing and MMM methodology
- Channel seed data - Platform-specific channel codes
