GAP DETECTION PLAYBOOK v5.0

VERSION: 5.5
DATE: January 2026
STATUS: Production Ready
COMPLIANCE: 6-Rule Compliant
================================================================================

This playbook defines the complete methodology for detecting gaps between projected outcomes and user targets, and for presenting structured options to close those gaps. The Media Planning Agent MUST use this playbook whenever projections fall short of stated objectives.

Gap detection and resolution is a core value-add of the agent. Users depend on the agent to:

- Identify when projections will not meet targets
- Quantify the gap precisely
- Present actionable options to close the gap
- Calculate the impact of each option
- Support unlimited iteration until user is satisfied
- Never rush to completion when gaps exist

This playbook applies to all gap scenarios including:

- PLANNING MODE: When initial projections miss targets
- IN-FLIGHT MODE: When actual performance trails planned performance
- POST-MORTEM MODE: When analyzing gaps between plan and actual for learnings
- All four adaptive pathways: EXPRESS, GUIDED
- All lifecycle modes: PLANNING, IN-FLIGHT, POST-MORTEM

Gap detection covers all measurable KPIs:

- Conversion gaps (conversions, leads, signups below target)
- Revenue gaps (revenue, ROAS below target)
- Efficiency gaps (CAC, CPA above target)
- Delivery gaps (impressions, reach below target)
- Engagement gaps (clicks, CTR below target)

PRINCIPLE 1: PROACTIVE DETECTION
The agent MUST proactively identify gaps without waiting for user to notice. If projections miss targets by more than 10 percent, the agent MUST flag the gap.

PRINCIPLE 2: QUANTIFIED OPTIONS
Every option MUST include specific calculations showing exactly how it closes the gap. Vague recommendations are not acceptable.

PRINCIPLE 3: UNLIMITED ITERATION
The user can iterate as many times as needed. The agent MUST never rush to completion or suggest settling for suboptimal outcomes.

PRINCIPLE 4: NO JUDGMENT
The agent presents options without judgment. If user chooses to increase budget, adjust goals, or combine approaches, all are equally valid paths forward.

PRINCIPLE 5: TRANSPARENT TRADE-OFFS
Every option has trade-offs. The agent MUST clearly articulate pros and cons for each option.

================================================================================

The agent MUST trigger gap detection when:

- Projected outcome is more than 10 percent below target
- Projected cost metric is more than 10 percent above target
- User explicitly asks about hitting targets
- In-flight actual is more than 15 percent behind plan

FORMULA: Gap Percentage
Gap Percent = ((Target - Projection) / Target) times 100

EXAMPLES:
- Target: 2,000 conversions, Projection: 1,600 conversions
- Gap: ((2000 - 1600) / 2000) times 100 = 20 percent gap

- Target CAC: 75 dollars, Projected CAC: 95 dollars
- Gap: ((95 - 75) / 75) times 100 = 26.7 percent over target

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The agent MUST quantify the gap in multiple ways:

ABSOLUTE GAP:
- The raw number difference between target and projection
- Example: 400 conversions short (2,000 target minus 1,600 projection)

PERCENTAGE GAP:
- The percentage shortfall from target
- Example: 20 percent below target

DOLLAR IMPACT:
- The revenue or cost impact of the gap
- Example: At 100 dollar AOV, 400 conversion gap equals 40,000 dollar revenue gap

EFFORT TO CLOSE:
- What improvement is needed to close the gap
- Example: Need 25 percent more conversions to hit target

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Before presenting options, the agent MUST identify the root cause:

BUDGET-DRIVEN GAP:
- Budget insufficient for target at current efficiency rates
- Symptom: All metrics proportionally short
- Solution focus: Increase budget or reduce target

EFFICIENCY-DRIVEN GAP:
- Budget adequate but efficiency (CTR, CVR) below benchmark
- Symptom: Impressions on track but conversions short
- Solution focus: Improve rates or adjust expectations

CHANNEL-DRIVEN GAP:
- Channel mix not optimal for objectives
- Symptom: Some channels overperforming, others underperforming
- Solution focus: Rebalance channel allocation

MARKET-DRIVEN GAP:
- External factors affecting performance
- Symptom: Benchmarks not holding in current conditions
- Solution focus: Adjust expectations or timing

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The agent MUST communicate gaps using this format:

"GAP DETECTED: Projection of [X] falls short of [target] by [Y] percent.

At current projections:
- You will achieve: [projection]
- Your target is: [target]
- Gap to close: [absolute gap] ([percentage] percent)
- Impact: [dollar or business impact]

Root cause assessment: [budget/efficiency/channel/market]

OPTIONS TO CLOSE GAP:
[Present 6 options with calculations]

Which option would you like to explore?"

================================================================================

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Increasing budget is the most direct path to closing a gap when efficiency rates are already at or near benchmark. This option calculates exactly how much additional budget is required to reach the target at current efficiency levels.

This option is appropriate when:
- Current efficiency metrics (CTR, CVR, CAC) are acceptable
- User has budget flexibility
- Timeline allows for additional spend
- Marginal efficiency is expected to remain stable

This option is NOT appropriate when:
- Efficiency metrics are poor (throwing money at a bad approach)
- User has fixed budget with no flexibility
- Market is saturated or audience exhausted
- Marginal efficiency is expected to decline significantly

FORMULA: Required Budget Increase

For conversion targets:
Additional Budget = Gap in Conversions times Current CAC
Total Required Budget = Current Budget plus Additional Budget

For revenue targets:
Additional Budget = Gap in Revenue divided by Current ROAS
Total Required Budget = Current Budget plus Additional Budget

For impression targets:
Additional Budget = Gap in Impressions divided by 1,000 times Current CPM
Total Required Budget = Current Budget plus Additional Budget

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Current budget: 150,000 dollars
- Current projection: 1,600 conversions
- Target: 2,000 conversions
- Gap: 400 conversions
- Current CAC: 93.75 dollars (150K divided by 1,600)
- Additional budget needed: 400 times 93.75 = 37,500 dollars
- Total required budget: 187,500 dollars
- Percentage increase: 25 percent

PROS:
- Most direct solution
- Does not require efficiency improvements
- Maintains current strategy and approach
- Scales existing proven performance
- Easier to implement (no optimization needed)

t

PROS:

- Maintains current strategy and approach
- Scales existing proven performance
- Easier to implement (no optimization needed)

CONS:
- Requires additional budget approval
- May not be available if budget is fixed
- Marginal efficiency may decline at scale
- Does not address underlying efficiency issues
- Opportunity cost of capital

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Improving conversion rate focuses on converting more of your existing traffic into customers. This option keeps budget and click volume constant while increasing the percentage of clicks that convert.

CVR improvement is often the highest-leverage option because:
- It improves efficiency without additional spend
- Changes can be implemented quickly (landing page, offer)
- Results compound with other improvements
- Does not require additional budget approval

This option is appropriate when:
- Current CVR is below benchmark for vertical
- Landing page has not been optimized recently
- Offer or value proposition can be strengthened
- Conversion funnel has identifiable friction points

This option is NOT appropriate when:
- CVR is already at or above benchmark
- Traffic quality is poor (wrong audience)
- Product-market fit issues exist
- Technical conversion tracking issues exist

FORMULA: Required CVR Improvement

Gap in Conversions = Target minus Projection
Current Conversions = Clicks times Current CVR
Required Conversions = Target
Required CVR = Target divided by Clicks

CVR Improvement Needed = (Required CVR minus Current CVR) divided by Current CVR times 100

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Current clicks: 64,286
- Current CVR: 2.50 percent
- Current conversions: 1,607
- Target: 2,000 conversions
- Required CVR: 2,000 divided by 64,286 = 3.11 percent
- CVR improvement needed: (3.11 minus 2.50) divided by 2.50 times 100 = 24.4 percent

PROS:
- No additional budget required
- Improves overall campaign efficiency
- Changes can be implemented quickly
- Benefits carry forward to future campaigns
- Often reveals optimization opportunities

ROS:
- No additional budget required
- Improves overall campaign efficiency
- Changes can be implemented quickly
- Benefits carry forward to future campaigns
- Often reveals optimization opportunities

CONS:
- 24 percent improvement may not be realistic
- Requires landing page or offer changes
- Results not guaranteed
- May require A/B testing time
- Could impact other metrics (quality of conversions)

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Improving click-through rate generates more clicks from the same impression volume, which flows through to more conversions if CVR holds constant. CTR improvements typically come from creative optimization, audience refinement, or placement selection.

CTR improvement is upstream of conversion, meaning:
- Every 1 percent CTR improvement flows through to conversion
- Compounds with CVR improvements
- Often indicates message-market fit improvements

This option is appropriate when:
- Current CTR is below benchmark for channel
- Creative has not been refreshed recently
- Audience targeting could be tightened
- Placements include low-engagement inventory

This option is NOT appropriate when:
- CTR is at or above benchmark
- Issue is CVR (clicks are fine, conversions are low)
- Creative is already highly optimized
- Audience is already tightly defined

FORMULA: Required CTR Improvement

Current Clicks = Impressions times Current CTR
Required Clicks = Target Conversions divided by Current CVR
Required CTR = Required Clicks divided by Impressions

CTR Improvement Needed = (Required CTR minus Current CTR) divided by Current CTR times 100

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Impressions: 10.71 million
- Current CTR: 0.60 percent
- Current clicks: 64,286
- Current CVR: 2.50 percent
- Target conversions: 2,000
- Required clicks: 2,000 divided by 0.025 = 80,000
- Required CTR: 80,000 divided by 10,710,000 = 0.747 percent
- CTR improvement needed: (0.747 minus 0.60) divided by 0.60 times 100 = 24.5 percent

PROS:
- No additional budget required
- Improves overall campaign efficiency
- Creative learnings apply to future campaigns
- May indicate improved message resonance
- Compounds with CVR improvements

- May indicate improved message resonance
- Compounds with CVR improvements

CONS:

- Requires creative resources to execute
- May take time to test and optimize
- Audience tightening may reduce scale
- Could impact conversion quality

CTR TESTING FRAMEWORK:

Phase 1: Initial launch (Days 1-7)
- Launch all variants with equal budget split
- Minimum 10,000 impressions per variant for statistical significance
- Measure: CTR, but also monitor downstream CVR

Phase 2: Cut underperformers (Day 8)
- Cut bottom 25-50 percent of variants (by CTR)
- Reallocate budget to top performers
- Continue testing with remaining variants

Phase 3: Optimize winners (Days 9-21)
- Double down on top 2-3 performers
- Create iterations of winning concepts
- Test new variants against winners

Phase 4: Steady state (Days 22+)
- Run proven winners at 70 percent of budget
- Test new variants with 30 percent of budget
- Rotate creative every 4-6 weeks to prevent fatigue

TIMELINE TO CTR IMPROVEMENT:

Day 1-7: Establish baseline with new creative (expect 10-15 percent immediate lift from freshness)
Day 8-14: Cut/optimize cycle (additional 5-10 percent lift)
Day 15-21: Proven winners scaled (stabilize at target CTR)

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Changing channel mix reallocates budget from lower-performing channels to higher-performing channels. This option recognizes that not all channels perform equally for every campaign, and optimization comes from shifting spend toward efficiency.

Channel mix optimization is often overlooked but can have significant impact:
- Different channels have different efficiency profiles
- Reallocating even 20-30 percent of budget can meaningfully improve results
- Insights apply to future campaign planning

This option is appropriate when:
- Campaign uses multiple channels
- Clear performance differences exist between channels
- Underperforming channel can be reduced without losing reach
- Higher-performing channel has room to scale

This option is NOT appropriate when:
- Single-channel campaign
- All channels performing similarly
- Higher-performing channel is at capacity
- Diverse channel presence is required (brand reasons)

FORMULA: Channel Mix Optimization

Current performance by channel:
Channel A: Budget A, Conversions A, CAC A
Channel B: Budget B, Conversions B, CAC B

Optimization: Shift budget from high-CAC to low-CAC channel

New allocation:
Channel A: Budget A plus Shift Amount
Channel B: Budget B minus Shift Amount

Projected new conversions:
New Total = (Budget A plus Shift) divided by CAC A plus (Budget B minus Shift) divided by CAC B

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Channel A (Meta): 90K budget, 1,125 conversions, 80 CAC
- Channel B (Display): 60K budget, 482 conversions, 124 CAC
- Total: 150K budget, 1,607 conversions, 93.4 CAC

Shift 20K from Display to Meta:
- Meta: 110K budget at 80 CAC = 1,375 conversions
- Display: 40K budget at 124 CAC = 323 conversions
- New total: 1,698 conversions (5.7 percent improvement)
- New CAC: 88.3 dollars

m Display to Meta:
- Meta: 110K budget at 80 CAC = 1,375 conversions
- Display: 40K budget at 124 CAC = 323 conversions
- New total: 1,698 conversions (5.7 percent improvement)
- New CAC: 88.3 dollars

PROS:
- No additional budget required
- Improves overall efficiency
- Quick to implement (targeting changes)
- Learnings inform future planning
- Often reveals hidden inefficiencies

CONS:
- May not fully close large gaps
- Reduces diversification
- Assumes scaling channel maintains efficiency
- May impact reach or audience coverage
- Could increase platform dependency

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Adjusting the goal means revising the target to a level that is achievable with current budget and efficiency rates. This is not admitting defeat - it is aligning expectations with reality.

Goal adjustment is appropriate when:
- Original target was set without sufficient data
- Market conditions have changed since target was set
- Budget constraints are fixed and non-negotiable
- Efficiency improvements are unlikely to materialize
- Gap is too large for realistic improvement

Goal adjustment is NOT appropriate when:
- User has not explored other options
- Budget flexibility exists
- Reasonable efficiency improvements could close gap
- Gap is small (under 10 percent)
- User has not acknowledged trade-offs

FORMULA: Realistic Goal Calculation

Realistic Goal = Budget divided by Current CAC

Or, with improvement assumptions:
Realistic Goal = Budget divided by (Current CAC times (1 minus Expected Improvement Percent))

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Budget: 150,000 dollars
- Current CAC: 93.40 dollars
- Realistic goal: 150,000 divided by 93.40 = 1,606 conversions

With 10 percent efficiency improvement:
- Adjusted CAC: 93.40 times 0.90 = 84.06 dollars
- Realistic goal: 150,000 divided by 84.06 = 1,785 conversions

PROS:
- Sets achievable expectations
- Reduces pressure and stress
- Allows team to focus on optimization
- May reveal that original target was unrealistic
- Provides learning for future planning

CONS:
- May feel like failure (perception issue)
- Stakeholders may resist
- Could impact downstream business plans
- May mask legitimate improvement opportunities
- Should be last resort after exploring options

feel like failure (perception issue)
- Stakeholders may resist
- Could impact downstream business plans
- May mask legitimate improvement opportunities
- Should be last resort after exploring options

USER: Our leadership set the 2,000 target. How do I communicate an adjustment?

AGENT: Communicating goal adjustments requires framing around learning and realism. Here's a recommended approach:

COMMUNICATION FRAMEWORK:

- ACKNOWLEDGE THE ORIGINAL TARGET
"Our initial target was 2,000 conversions based on [assumptions or industry benchmarks]."

- SHARE WHAT WE'VE LEARNED
"Through planning analysis, we've identified that achieving 2,000 conversions would require either:
- 25 percent additional budget (187.5K vs 150K), OR
- 25 percent efficiency improvement over benchmarks, OR
- Both

- PRESENT THE REALISTIC RANGE
"Based on our budget of 150K and realistic efficiency assumptions, we project:
- Base case: 1,600-1,700 conversions
- Optimistic case: 1,800-1,900 conversions
- Stretch case: 1,900-2,000 conversions (requires aggressive optimization)"

- OFFER OPTIONS
"We have three paths forward:
A) Increase budget to 187.5K to hit 2,000 with confidence
B) Maintain 150K and target 1,750 with optimization
C) Maintain 150K and 2,000 target, accepting higher risk of shortfall"

- MAKE A RECOMMENDATION
"I recommend Option B: Target 1,750 conversions with optimization efforts. This is achievable with 70 percent confidence and positions us to exceed expectations rather than miss an aggressive target."

FULL DESCRIPTION:
Combining approaches uses multiple levers simultaneously to close the gap. This is often the most practical option because it distributes the required improvement across multiple realistic changes rather than requiring dramatic improvement in a single area.

Combining approaches is appropriate when:
- Single option alone cannot close the gap
- User has some budget flexibility
- Some efficiency improvement is realistic
- Channel mix has optimization potential
- User prefers balanced, lower-risk approach

This is the DEFAULT RECOMMENDATION for gaps larger than 15 percent because:
- Distributes risk across multiple interventions
- Each individual improvement is more achievable
- Creates compounding effects
- Provides multiple paths to success

FORMULA: Combined Approach Calculation

Gap = Target minus Current Projection

Option 1 contribution: X conversions (from budget increase)
Option 2 contribution: Y conversions (from CVR improvement)
Option 3 contribution: Z conversions (from channel mix)

Required: X plus Y plus Z is greater than or equal to Gap

CALCULATION EXAMPLE:
- Gap: 400 conversions
- Budget increase of 15K: Plus 161 conversions (15K at 93 CAC)
- CVR improvement of 10 percent: Plus 161 conversions (10 percent of 1,607)
- Channel shift: Plus 89 conversions (from earlier calculation)
- Total: Plus 411 conversions (closes 400 gap with buffer)

PROS:
- Most achievable approach for large gaps
- Distributes risk across interventions
- Each improvement is modest and realistic
- Creates sustainable efficiency gains
- Provides multiple paths if one intervention underperforms

CONS:
- Requires coordination across multiple workstreams
- More complex to implement and track
- May require both budget and effort
- Success depends on multiple factors
- Harder to attribute results to specific changes

CORE RULE: The user can iterate as many times as needed until satisfied. The agent MUST never rush to completion, express impatience, or suggest settling for suboptimal outcomes.

ITERATION TRIGGERS:
- User asks "what if" questions
- User wants to see different scenarios
- User provides new constraints or information
- User is not satisfied with current options
- User wants to combine options differently

AGENT RESPONSE TO ITERATION REQUESTS:
- Always respond with full calculations
- Never say "we've already covered this"
- Never express fatigue or impatience
- Treat each iteration as fresh and valuable
- Build on previous iterations, don't start over

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The agent MUST track iterations for reference:

ITERATION LOG FORMAT:
"Iteration [N]: [Description]
- Scenario: [key parameters]
- Projection: [outcome]
- Gap status: [CLOSED/PARTIAL/OPEN]
- User feedback: [response]"

EXAMPLE:
"Iteration 1: Baseline projection
- Budget: 150K, no optimization
- Projection: 1,607 conversions
- Gap status: OPEN (20 percent short)
- User feedback: Explore options

Iteration 2: Budget increase only
- Budget: 187.5K
- Projection: 2,000 conversions
- Gap status: CLOSED
- User feedback: Too much budget, try efficiency

Iteration 3: CVR improvement only
- Budget: 150K, CVR +24%
- Projection: 2,000 conversions
- Gap status: CLOSED but aggressive
- User feedback: Combine with smaller improvements

Iteration 4: Combined approach
- Budget: 150K, CVR +10%, CTR +10%, channel shift
- Projection: 2,020 conversions
- Gap status: CLOSED with buffer
- User feedback: APPROVED"

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If user wants to revisit an earlier option:

AGENT RESPONSE:
"Of course. Let me pull up [Option X] from our earlier discussion.

[Restate the option details]

Would you like to:
A) Proceed with this option as discussed
B) Modify it with new parameters
C) Compare it against our later options"

Never make user feel bad for revisiting. Iteration is the path to the right decision.

sectionTitle: 5.3 WHEN USER RETURNS TO EARLIER OPTIONS
SECTION 6: WHEN TO RECOMMEND GOAL ADJUSTMENT

content:
The agent SHOULD proactively recommend goal adjustment when:

SIGN 1: GAP EXCEEDS 30 PERCENT
- A 30+ percent gap typically requires unrealistic improvements
- Either massive budget increase or exceptional efficiency gains
- Goal adjustment provides more reliable path

EXAMPLE:
"Your gap is 35 percent, which would require a 54 percent budget increase or 35+ percent efficiency improvement. Both are extremely aggressive. I recommend we discuss a realistic target that your team can achieve with confidence."

SIGN 2: BUDGET IS ABSOLUTELY FIXED
- User has clearly stated no additional budget is possible
- All budget-based options are off the table
- Efficiency improvements alone cannot close gap

EXAMPLE:
"With your fixed 150K budget, closing the 25 percent gap requires efficiency improvements that exceed industry best practices. A more achievable target of 1,700 conversions would set your team up for success."

SIGN 3: EFFICIENCY ALREADY AT BENCHMARK
- Current CTR and CVR are at or above vertical benchmarks
- Little room for improvement
- Budget is the only lever, but budget is constrained

EXAMPLE:
"Your CTR of 1.2 percent and CVR of 3.5 percent are already above benchmark. There's limited improvement potential. The gap is a budget issue, not an efficiency issue. If budget cannot increase, we should adjust the target."

SIGN 4: TIMELINE PREVENTS OPTIMIZATION
- Campaign is too short for meaningful optimization
- No time for A/B testing or iteration
- What you launch with is what you get

EXAMPLE:
"With a 2-week campaign, there's no time for the optimization needed to close this gap. You're launching with current creative and landing page. I recommend targeting 800 conversions rather than 1,000 to set achievable expectations."
sectionTitle: 6.1 SIGNS THAT GOAL ADJUSTMENT IS APPROPRIATE

content:
no time for the optimization needed to close this gap. You're launching with current creative and landing page. I recommend targeting 800 conversions rather than 1,000 to set achievable expectations."

SIGN 5: MARKET CONDITIONS HAVE CHANGED
- Original target was set under different conditions
- CPMs have increased significantly
- Competitive landscape has shifted
- Economic factors have impacted conversion behavior

EXAMPLE:
"When you set the 2,000 target, CPMs were running 12-15 dollars. Current CPMs are 18-22 dollars due to holiday season. The same budget now buys fewer impressions. I recommend adjusting to 1,650 conversions to reflect current market reality."

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sectionTitle: 6.1 SIGNS THAT GOAL ADJUSTMENT IS APPROPRIATE

content:
FRAMING PRINCIPLES:
- Never frame as failure or giving up
- Position as data-driven decision making
- Emphasize what IS achievable, not what is not
- Provide the realistic number, not just "lower"
- Explain the path to the adjusted goal

RECOMMENDED LANGUAGE:

"Based on our analysis, here's what I recommend:

Your original target of 2,000 conversions would require [X condition] which [is not available / is unrealistic / carries high risk].

A realistic, achievable target is 1,750 conversions. This target:
- Is achievable with [Y conditions]
- Gives your team room to exceed
- Reduces pressure and risk
- Aligns expectations with resources

This is not lowering expectations - it's aligning expectations with reality. Many campaigns fail because they chase unrealistic targets instead of optimizing for what's achievable.

Would you like me to build the plan for 1,750 conversions?"

================================================================================

USER: We have 200K budget for holiday. Need 5,000 orders. Can we do it?

AGENT: Let me run the numbers for your holiday campaign.

At 200K budget, I need a few inputs:
- What's your typical AOV?
- Which channels are you planning to use?
- What were your results last holiday season?

USER: AOV is 75 dollars. Using Meta and Google. Last year we got 3,200 orders on 180K spend.

AGENT: Great context. Let me calculate:

LAST YEAR BASELINE:
- Spend: 180,000 dollars
- Orders: 3,200
- CPA: 56.25 dollars

THIS YEAR PROJECTION (assuming same efficiency):
- Spend: 200,000 dollars
- CPA: 56.25 dollars
- Orders: 3,556

GAP DETECTED:
- Target: 5,000 orders
- Projection: 3,556 orders
- Gap: 1,444 orders (29 percent short)

This is a significant gap. To hit 5,000 orders at your historical CPA, you'd need 281,250 dollars budget.

Shall I present options to close this gap?

USER: Yes, but we can't increase budget beyond 200K.

AGENT: Understood - 200K is fixed. Let me recalculate options without budget increase.

To close a 29 percent gap with efficiency alone, you'd need to reduce CPA from 56.25 to 40 dollars. That's a 29 percent improvement - very aggressive for holiday when CPMs typically increase.

OPTIONS WITHOUT BUDGET INCREASE:

OPTION 2: IMPROVE CVR
- Required: 40 percent improvement (extremely aggressive)
- Assessment: NOT REALISTIC

OPTION 3: IMPROVE CTR
- Required: 40 percent improvement
- Assessment: NOT REALISTIC

OPTION 4: CHANGE CHANNEL MIX
- Current split: Unknown

TRIGGER: Gap greater than 10 percent from target

COMMUNICATION FORMAT:
"GAP DETECTED: Projection of [X] falls short of [target] by [Y] percent.

OPTIONS TO CLOSE GAP:
- INCREASE BUDGET - Add [amount] to reach target
- IMPROVE CVR - If CVR improves to [X], you hit target
- IMPROVE CTR - If CTR improves to [X], you hit target
- CHANGE CHANNEL MIX - Reallocate to higher-efficiency channels
- ADJUST GOAL - Realistic target is [X]
- COMBINE APPROACHES - [specific combination]

Which would you like to explore?"

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WHEN TO RECOMMEND EACH OPTION:

INCREASE BUDGET:
- Efficiency is acceptable
- Budget flexibility exists
- Fastest path to target

IMPROVE CVR:
- CVR is below benchmark
- Landing page not optimized
- Conversion funnel has friction

IMPROVE CTR:
- CTR is below benchmark
- Creative is stale
- Audience can be refined

CHANGE CHANNEL MIX:
- Multiple channels in use
- Clear performance differences
- Room to scale winner

ADJUST GOAL:
- Gap exceeds 30 percent
- Budget is fixed
- Efficiency already optimized
- Timeline prevents optimization

COMBINE APPROACHES:
- Gap exceeds 15 percent
- Multiple levers available
- User prefers balanced risk

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

- User can iterate unlimited times
- Never express impatience
- Track iterations for reference
- Build on previous work
- Each scenario deserves full calculation

When the agent performs web research to gather benchmark data, validate assumptions, or fill information gaps, it MUST follow these constraints:

DOMAIN RESTRICTIONS:

Preferred sources (HIGH trust):
- Industry research firms (eMarketer, Statista, IAB, Nielsen)
- Major advertising trade publications (AdAge, AdWeek, Marketing Week)
- Platform official documentation (Meta Business Help, Google Ads Help)
- Academic and government sources (WARC, Census, BLS)

Acceptable sources (MEDIUM trust):
- Established marketing blogs with cited data
- Industry association reports
- Recognized analyst commentary

Avoided sources (LOW or NO trust):
- User-generated content without verification
- Promotional content and vendor whitepapers with obvious bias
- Sponsored results and paid placements
- Anonymous forum posts or comments
- Competitor internal documents or leaked materials

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Data volatility determines required recency:

VOLATILE METRICS (prefer last 3 months):
- CPM rates (especially programmatic)
- CPC rates
- Platform-specific costs
- Auction-based pricing

SEMI-STABLE METRICS (last 12 months acceptable):
- CTR benchmarks by vertical
- Conversion rate ranges
- General market trends

STABLE METRICS (last 24 months acceptable):
- Measurement methodologies
- Attribution models
- General best practices

When using older data:
- Explicitly note the publication date
- Downgrade confidence level by one tier
- Suggest user verify with current conditions

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SINGLE SOURCE DATA:
- Flag as "unverified single source"
- Recommend cross-reference before relying heavily
- Assign MEDIUM-LOW confidence maximum

MULTIPLE SOURCE CORROBORATION:
- Two agreeing sources: MEDIUM confidence
- Three or more agreeing sources: MEDIUM-HIGH confidence
- Conflicting sources: Present range, note disagreement

SPECULATION VS FACT:
- Never present speculation as fact
- Clearly label forward-looking statements
- Distinguish between reported data and analyst opinion

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The agent MUST NOT search for or use:

- Personal information about individuals (PII)
- Confidential competitor financial data
- Non-public company information
- Trade secrets or proprietary methodologies
- Content explicitly behind paywalls
- Information that appears to be leaked or stolen

If accidentally accessing prohibited content:
- Do not quote or summarize the content
- Note that protected content was encountered
- Seek alternative public sources

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Every piece of web-sourced data MUST include:

REQUIRED CITATION ELEMENTS:
- Source organization or publication name
- Publication or retrieval date
- URL if available
- Confidence level assigned

EXAMPLE CITATION FORMAT:
"CPM benchmark: 12 to 18 dollars for retail paid social"
[Source: eMarketer, Q3 2025 report, Retrieved: January 2026, Confidence: MEDIUM-HIGH]

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Web research is Priority 2 in the Data Source Hierarchy:

Priority 1: API/Dataverse data (VERIFIED) - Always prefer when available
Priority 2: Live web research (RESEARCHED) - Use when API data unavailable
Priority 3: User-provided data (CLIENT-PROVIDED) - Current session context
Priority 4: Historical plan data (HISTORICAL) - Previous client plans
Priority 5: Default benchmarks (ESTIMATED) - Last resort only

When moving to web research from API:
- Explicitly note that API data was unavailable
- Apply research constraints from this section
- Adjust confidence level appropriately

See DATA_SOURCE_HIERARCHY.txt for complete data priority documentation.

Every substantive response MUST include ALL FOUR of these elements. Check your response before sending.

ELEMENT 1 CONTEXT CALLBACK

Start by referencing established facts. Use phrases like:
- With your 250K budget...
- Building on your ecommerce business...
- Given your 5000 customer target...
- Based on the remittance vertical you mentioned...

NEVER respond as if starting fresh. ALWAYS anchor to what you know.

ELEMENT 2 CALCULATION

Show your math. When you have budget and target, divide them. When you have LTV and CAC, compute ratio. ALWAYS show the arithmetic.

CORRECT: 250K divided by 5000 equals 50 per customer.
CORRECT: With 85 LTV and 50 CAC, your ratio is 1.7 to 1.
WRONG: Your cost per customer would be reasonable.

ELEMENT 3 KB BENCHMARK CITATION

When stating typical ranges, ALWAYS say Based on KB data for your vertical. NEVER state benchmarks without KB attribution.

CORRECT: Based on KB data for ecommerce, typical CAC runs 35 to 65.
CORRECT: Based on KB data for remittance, typical CAC runs 45 to 75.
WRONG: Typical CAC is around 50.
WRONG: Industry benchmarks suggest 50.

See KB_Benchmark_Reference_v6_6 for comprehensive benchmark data across all verticals.

ELEMENT 4 VERTICAL REFERENCE

Name the user's vertical or industry in your benchmark statements.

sectionTitle: RESPONSE SEQUENCE WHEN YOU HAVE DATA

content:
When user provides any target, compare to KB benchmarks and label it:

CONSERVATIVE: Target is 20% or more below typical range. User has buffer for testing and learning.

REALISTIC: Target is within typical range. Achievable with solid execution.

AGGRESSIVE: Target is 10-30% above typical range. Requires tight targeting and efficient channels.

VERY AGGRESSIVE: Target is more than 30% above typical range. Requires exceptional execution. Explain specifically what must go right.

User says: We have 250K to acquire 5000 customers in ecommerce.

CORRECT RESPONSE:
With your 250K budget and 5000 customer target, that implies 50 per customer. Based on KB data for ecommerce, typical CAC runs 35 to 65. Your 50 target is REALISTIC - right in the middle of the range. Achievable with solid execution.

Do you have existing customer data? I can analyze it with ADIS to identify high-value segments and optimize targeting.

WRONG RESPONSE:
Great, that helps. A few questions: What is your timeline? Which channels are you considering? Do you have a target CAC in mind?

When user mentions customer data, transaction files, CRM exports, segmentation, RFM, CLV, or asks about best customers, offer ADIS analysis.

ADIS PROMPT:
I can analyze your customer data to identify segments and optimize targeting. Upload your file to get started.

ADIS supports EIGHT analytical models. Reference the appropriate model for the situation:

MODEL 1 RFM SEGMENTATION
Use when user needs behavioral customer segments based on recency, frequency, and monetary value. Creates segments like Champions, Loyal Customers, At Risk, and Lost.

MODEL 2 DECILE ANALYSIS
Use when user needs value-based stratification into ten equal groups. Shows Pareto concentration and Gini coefficient.

MODEL 3 COHORT ANALYSIS
Use when user needs to track customer groups over time for retention patterns. Supports monthly, weekly, or quarterly cohorts.

MODEL 4 DETERMINISTIC CLV
Use when user needs rule-based lifetime value calculation using historical averages. Good starting point when data is limited.

MODEL 5 PROBABILISTIC CLV
Use when user needs statistical LTV predictions with uncertainty quantification using BG-NBD model. Requires more data but provides probability customer is still active.

MODEL 6 K-MEANS CLUSTERING
Use when user wants natural customer groupings to emerge from data patterns. Good for discovering segments you did not know existed.

s probability customer is still active.

MODEL 6 K-MEANS CLUSTERING
Use when user wants natural customer groupings to emerge from data patterns. Good for discovering segments you did not know existed.

MODEL 7 PROPENSITY MODEL
Use when user has labeled outcomes and wants to predict likelihood of specific behaviors like purchase, churn, or upgrade.

MODEL 8 UPLIFT MODEL
Use when user needs to identify customers most responsive to specific treatments or offers. Requires treatment and control data.

Step 3-4 Audience: Ask if user has customer transaction data. ADIS can segment customers and recommend channels by segment value.

Step 5 Budget: With ADIS audiences, offer AMMO optimization to allocate budget across segments using channel affinity.

Step 7 Channels: With ADIS data, reference segment affinity scores. Champions may respond best to email and direct mail. At Risk customers may respond best to retargeting.

See ADIS_Quick_Reference_v2 for complete model specifications and ADIS_Copilot_Integration_v2 for step-specific prompts.

When you say Locked or Step complete, you create a binding record.

WHAT CONSTITUTES A LOCK:

- Saying Step X complete with summary
- Confirming with Got it, we will use X

LOCK TRACKING REQUIREMENTS:
- Maintain mental ledger of all locked decisions
- Reference locked decisions when relevant
- NEVER claim uncertainty about previously locked items
- If user questions what was locked, state the decision clearly

LOCK VIOLATIONS TO AVOID:
- Saying We have not formally locked this when you said Locked earlier
- Asking user to re-confirm decisions already locked
- Forgetting agreed parameters like DMA lists, KPIs, or targets

AUDIENCE AND TARGETING SOPHISTICATION GUIDE v5.8

VERSION 5.8
DATE January 2026
STATUS Production Ready
DOCUMENT TYPE Knowledge Base - Audience Strategy Foundation
COMPLIANCE 6-Rule Compliant

This document provides guidance on how to scale audience definition rigor based on objective type, budget size, and risk profile. It helps the agent determine when to push for more sophistication and when simpler approaches are appropriate. All audience definitions must include census-validated sizing and platform taxonomy codes for activation.

Audience sophistication should match the precision required by the objective. Brand building with broad reach requires less targeting precision than performance marketing with tight efficiency requirements. Over-targeting can reduce scale. Under-targeting can waste budget. The goal is appropriate precision with activation-ready outputs.

Tier 1 represents broad reach appropriate for brand and upper-funnel objectives. Signal count is approximately 5 to 10. Focus is on basic demographic alignment, broad interest categories, contextual relevance, and geographic targeting. This tier is appropriate when the objective is awareness or consideration, the audience is broad by design, budget is sufficient for wide reach, and learning is more valuable than immediate efficiency.

Tier 2 represents moderate precision appropriate for mid-funnel and consideration objectives. Signal count is approximately 10 to 20. Focus is on more specific behavioral signals, purchase intent indicators, category interest, competitive consideration, and life-stage targeting. This tier is appropriate when the objective is consideration or preference, the audience has identifiable characteristics, efficiency matters but is not the primary constraint, and some testing budget exists.

Tier 3 represents high precision appropriate for performance and lower-funnel objectives. Signal count is approximately 20 to 40 where feasible. Focus is on strong intent signals, recency indicators, predictive modeling, custom audiences, lookalike expansion from high-value customers, and cross-device and cross-channel coordination. This tier is appropriate when the objective is conversion or revenue, efficiency targets are tight, data is available to support precision, and measurement can attribute results.

Demographic signals include age, gender, income, education, occupation, household composition, and life stage. These are foundational but often insufficient alone. Over-reliance on demographics when behavioral data exists is a common mistake. Census data provides the base population for demographic filtering.

Behavioral signals include past purchase behavior, browsing history, engagement patterns, content consumption, search behavior, and app usage. These are generally more predictive than demographics. Availability varies by platform and data partnerships. Google In-Market and Meta Behaviors are primary sources.

Contextual signals include content adjacency, time of day, device type, location context, and environmental factors. These matter for brand safety and relevance. Increasingly important in privacy-constrained environments. IAB Content Taxonomy provides standard categorization.

Intent signals include search queries, comparison behavior, cart abandonment, pricing page visits, and review reading. These are the strongest performance indicators. Limited availability and often expensive to acquire.

Psychographic signals include values, attitudes, interests, lifestyle, and brand affinity. Useful for message alignment and creative strategy. Often less reliable than behavioral signals. Meta Interests and Google Affinity are primary sources.

Audience size must support objective scale. Common calculation: Required reach equals target conversions divided by expected conversion rate divided by expected reach-to-action ratio. If required reach exceeds addressable audience, either objective must be adjusted or audience must be expanded.

Census Validation Requirement: All audience size estimates must start with census-validated population data for the target geography. The agent must web search for current census data before presenting audience sizing.

Warning signs of audience-scale mismatch include targeting that produces very high CPMs, frequency that climbs rapidly, performance that degrades as spend increases, and difficulty achieving spend targets.

More precise targeting typically costs more per impression but should deliver better efficiency. The relationship is not always linear. Key questions to assess tradeoff: Does the targeting premium pay back in conversion lift? Is the efficiency gain sustainable at scale? Are we over-paying for precision that does not improve outcomes?

First-party data from the advertiser is highest value and most reliable but limited in scale. Second-party data from partners is useful for extension but quality varies. Third-party data from data providers offers scale but declining accuracy and privacy constraints. Platform data from channels offers strong within-platform signals but walled gardens limit cross-channel view. Modeled data from look-alikes and predictions is useful for scale but can decay quickly.

ACTIVATION-READY OUTPUT REQUIREMENTS

Complete audience definitions must include platform-specific taxonomy codes that enable direct activation without manual translation.

Required Output Components:
- IAB Content Taxonomy codes for contextual targeting
- Google Affinity Audience codes for GDN and DV360
- Google In-Market Audience codes for intent targeting
- Meta Detailed Targeting parameters for Facebook and Instagram
- LinkedIn targeting parameters if B2B relevant

The agent must web search for current taxonomy codes rather than relying on potentially outdated information. See MPA_Audience_Taxonomy_Structure_v5_8 for search patterns and format requirements.
sectionTitle: DATA SOURCE HIERARCHY FOR AUDIENCE SIGNALS

content: A well-defined audience should answer these questions: Who specifically are we trying to reach? What do we know about their current state awareness consideration or purchase? What signals indicate they are a good target? Where can we reach them at scale? How large is this audience based on census data? What data do we have to find them? What targeting limitations exist by channel? What taxonomy codes enable activation?

Defining audience by demographics alone when behavioral data exists. Targeting too narrowly for the objective scale. Using internal jargon or assumed knowledge rather than verifiable signals. Confusing the customer we want with the customer we can reach. Not accounting for privacy constraints and data deprecation. Assuming targeting capabilities that do not exist in planned channels. Presenting audience sizes without census validation. Omitting taxonomy codes that enable direct activation.

Audience targeting is constrained by evolving privacy regulation and platform policies. Current realities: Third-party cookies are deprecated or limited. Mobile identifiers are opt-in and declining. Cross-site tracking is increasingly restricted. Platform data stays within walled gardens.

Implications for planning: First-party data strategy is increasingly critical. Contextual targeting is having a renaissance. Modeled and aggregated approaches are replacing individual-level targeting. Measurement is more difficult as targeting becomes less precise. IAB Content Taxonomy provides privacy-safe contextual options.

Start with objective type. If brand or awareness, begin at Tier 1 unless specific reason for more precision. If consideration, begin at Tier 2. If performance, begin at Tier 3.

Then assess budget relative to audience size. If budget is limited relative to audience, reduce precision to improve reach. If budget is sufficient, maintain appropriate precision.

Then assess data availability. If signals are not available, cannot target on them regardless of desire. Adjust plan to data reality.

Then assess measurement capability. More precise targeting requires more precise measurement to validate. If measurement cannot distinguish targeting approaches, simplicity may be preferred.

Push for more sophistication when efficiency targets are aggressive and data exists to support precision, when performance is below expectation and targeting is a plausible cause, when budget is large enough to test multiple approaches, when measurement can validate improvement, and when competitive pressure requires better targeting.
sectionTitle: WHEN TO PUSH FOR MORE SOPHISTICATION

content: Accept simpler approaches when objective is reach-oriented and precision is not required, when data to support sophisticated targeting does not exist, when budget does not support testing, when measurement cannot validate improvement, and when additional complexity will not change outcomes.

A complete audience strategy for the media plan should include primary target audience description, signal categories and specific signals used, targeting approach by channel, expected audience size with census-validated methodology, data sources for targeting with citations, known limitations and gaps, testing approach for audience refinement, and platform taxonomy codes for activation.

CROSS-REFERENCES

Related Documents:
- MPA_Audience_Dimension_Checklist_v5_8 - Complete 4-dimension signal requirements with census and taxonomy output formats
- MPA_Audience_Taxonomy_Structure_v5_8 - IAB, Google, Meta, LinkedIn taxonomy structures and search patterns
- MPA_Geography_DMA_Planning_v5_8 - Census data requirements and geography table format
- MPA_Expert_Lens_Audience_Strategy - Diagnostic patterns and audience sizing guidelines
- MPA_Implications_Audience_Targeting - Downstream effects of audience decisions

The agent MUST use web search when:
- Validating population data for any geography
- Retrieving current platform taxonomy codes
- Checking platform-specific targeting updates
- Verifying privacy regulation impacts on targeting
- Finding vertical-specific audience benchmarks

DOCUMENT: MEASUREMENT_FRAMEWORK_v5_5.txt
CATEGORY: Framework
TOPICS: measurement, attribution, KPIs, conversion tracking, analytics, ROI

MEASUREMENT FRAMEWORK v5.5

================================================================================

================================================================================

VERSION: 5.5
DATE: January 2026
STATUS: Production Ready
COMPLIANCE: 6-Rule Compliant
PURPOSE: Measurement strategy, attribution model selection, conversion tracking

================================================================================

================================================================================

This document provides systematic guidance for measurement strategy, attribution model selection, conversion tracking, and performance evaluation across campaign types. The agent should use this framework to recommend appropriate measurement approaches while adapting to user data availability and organizational maturity.

================================================================================

================================================================================

If this document does not contain relevant guidance for a specific measurement scenario:
- Research current best practices using available tools
- Apply general measurement principles to novel situations
- Clearly state when recommendations are based on general principles versus documented guidance
- Never fail or error due to missing information - adapt and inform the user

If user measurement approaches conflict with best practices in this document:
- Present the recommended approach with rationale
- Acknowledge organizational constraints or legacy systems
- Proceed with user direction if they confirm after seeing the recommendation
- Do not repeatedly challenge user decisions after initial guidance

================================================================================

================================================================================

Measurement exists to inform decisions, not to prove success. The goal is accurate understanding of marketing impact, not favorable reporting. Honest measurement enables optimization. Biased measurement enables waste.

================================================================================

================================================================================

Modern measurement requires three complementary approaches working together:

MARKETING MIX MODELING (MMM)
- Top-down statistical analysis using aggregate data
- Measures impact of all channels including offline
- Accounts for external factors (seasonality, economy, competition)
- Strategic planning timeframe (quarterly, annually)
- Privacy-safe (no user-level tracking required)
- Best for: Budget allocation decisions, channel mix optimization, long-term planning

MULTI-TOUCH ATTRIBUTION (MTA)
- Bottom-up analysis using user-level journey data
- Assigns credit to digital touchpoints
- Near real-time optimization insights
- Tactical execution timeframe (daily, weekly)
- Requires user-level tracking (privacy challenged)
- Best for: In-flight optimization, creative testing, tactical decisions

- Controlled experiments measuring true causal impact
- Holdout groups establish baseline
- Isolates marketing effect from organic demand
- Campaign or test timeframe
- Gold standard for proving causation
- Best for: Validating channel value, major budget decisions, new channel evaluation

No single measurement approach provides complete truth. Triangulate findings across methods:
- If MMM and MTA agree: High confidence in finding
- If MMM and incrementality agree: Strong evidence for strategic decision
- If MTA and incrementality disagree: Investigate attribution model assumptions
- If all three disagree: Examine data quality and methodology

================================================================================

================================================================================

SINGLE-TOUCH MODELS

First-Touch Attribution
- Assigns 100 percent credit to first interaction
- Best for: Understanding awareness channel effectiveness
- Weakness: Ignores conversion drivers
- Use when: Evaluating top-of-funnel campaigns, simple acquisition funnels

Last-Touch Attribution
- Assigns 100 percent credit to final interaction before conversion
- Best for: Understanding immediate conversion triggers
- Weakness: Ignores awareness and consideration drivers
- Use when: Short purchase cycles, direct response campaigns, limited data

Last Non-Direct Click
- Assigns credit to last marketing touchpoint (excludes direct)
- Best for: Understanding which marketing drove conversion
- Weakness: Still ignores earlier touchpoints
- Use when: Default in many platforms, acceptable starting point

MULTI-TOUCH MODELS

Linear Attribution
- Distributes credit equally across all touchpoints
- Best for: Acknowledging full journey contribution
- Weakness: No differentiation by touchpoint value
- Use when: Long consideration cycles, B2B with many touchpoints

Time-Decay Attribution
- Weights touchpoints closer to conversion more heavily
- Best for: Recognizing recency importance
- Weakness: May undervalue awareness
- Use when: Moderate sales cycles, consideration-heavy purchases

Position-Based (U-Shaped)
- 40 percent to first touch, 40 percent to last touch, 20 percent distributed middle
- Best for: Valuing both awareness and conversion
- Weakness: Arbitrary weighting
- Use when: Balanced full-funnel campaigns

ent to first touch, 40 percent to last touch, 20 percent distributed middle
- Best for: Valuing both awareness and conversion
- Weakness: Arbitrary weighting
- Use when: Balanced full-funnel campaigns

W-Shaped Attribution
- Credit to first touch, lead creation, and opportunity creation
- Best for: B2B with defined funnel stages
- Weakness: Requires clear stage definitions
- Use when: B2B campaigns with CRM integration

Data-Driven (Algorithmic)
- Machine learning assigns credit based on conversion probability impact
- Best for: Large datasets with sufficient conversion volume
- Weakness: Requires substantial data, black box methodology
- Use when: High conversion volume, sophisticated measurement needs

- Primary Model: First-Touch
- Supporting: Linear (to see full journey)
- Rationale: Awareness channels rarely get last-touch credit despite driving demand
- Key Consideration: Use brand lift studies alongside attribution
sectionTitle: ATTRIBUTION MODEL SELECTION BY CAMPAIGN TYPE AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS

content:
- Primary Model: Linear or Time-Decay
- Supporting: Position-Based
- Rationale: Middle funnel deserves proportional credit
- Key Consideration: Define consideration actions clearly (content consumption, site engagement)

- Primary Model: Last-Touch or Time-Decay
- Supporting: Data-Driven if volume supports
- Rationale: Focus on conversion efficiency
- Key Consideration: Ensure proper conversion tracking across all touchpoints

FULL-FUNNEL CAMPAIGNS
- Primary Model: Position-Based or Data-Driven
- Supporting: View across all models for different insights
- Rationale: Need to value both awareness and conversion
- Key Consideration: Align attribution model with budget allocation philosophy

B2B LONG-CYCLE CAMPAIGNS
- Primary Model: W-Shaped or Custom multi-touch
- Supporting: Account-level attribution
- Rationale: Long cycles with multiple stakeholders need full journey view
- Key Consideration: Integrate CRM data with marketing touchpoints

Macro Conversions (Primary Business Outcomes):
- Purchase/Transaction
- Lead submission (qualified)
- Subscription/Sign-up
- Contract/Deal closed

Micro Conversions (Leading Indicators):
- Add to cart
- Form start
- Content download
- Demo request
- Pricing page view
- Email sign-up

Engagement Actions (Consideration Signals):
- Video completion
- Time on site threshold
- Page depth
- Return visit
- Social engagement
sectionTitle: CONVERSION TRACKING BEST PRACTICES CONVERSION DEFINITION HIERARCHY

content:
Platform-Specific Pixels:
- Meta Pixel and Conversions API
- Google Ads conversion tracking
- LinkedIn Insight Tag
- TikTok Pixel
- Twitter/X conversion tracking

Server-Side Tracking:
- Implement for privacy compliance
- Reduces data loss from browser restrictions
- Required for accurate measurement post-cookie
- Conversions API, Enhanced Conversions, server containers

Offline Conversion Import:
- CRM integration for lead quality
- In-store purchase tracking
- Call tracking attribution
- Offline event uploads

Default Recommendations by Conversion Type:
- Impulse purchase (under 50 dollars): 7-day click, 1-day view
- Considered purchase (50-500 dollars): 14-day click, 7-day view
- High-value purchase (over 500 dollars): 28-day click, 7-day view
- B2B lead generation: 30-90 day click, 7-day view
- B2B enterprise: 90-180 day click, 30-day view

Lookback Window Considerations:
- Match window to actual purchase cycle
- Longer windows capture more conversions but may over-attribute
- Shorter windows are more conservative but may miss influence
- Align windows across platforms for fair comparison

First-Party Data Integration:
- Hash customer data for privacy-safe matching
- Email, phone, address for identity resolution
- Improves cross-device attribution
- Required as third-party cookies deprecate

Enhanced Conversions Setup:
- Google: Enhanced Conversions for Web and Leads
- Meta: Conversions API with customer information parameters
- LinkedIn: Offline Conversions API

Consent Management:
- Respect user opt-outs
- Implement consent mode
- Model conversions for opted-out users
- Maintain compliance with GDPR, CCPA, other regulations

Primary KPIs:
- Reach (unique users exposed)
- Frequency (average exposures per user)
- Brand Lift (survey-based awareness change)
- Share of Voice (competitive presence)

Secondary KPIs:
- CPM (cost per thousand impressions)
- Video Completion Rate
- Viewability Rate
- Brand Search Lift (increase in brand searches)

Benchmarks and Targets:
- Aim for 3-5 frequency over campaign flight
- Video completion 70 percent plus for 15-second, 50 percent plus for 30-second
- Viewability 70 percent plus (MRC standard)
- Brand lift 3-5 points is meaningful change
sectionTitle: KEY METRICS BY CAMPAIGN OBJECTIVE AWARENESS CAMPAIGN METRICS

content:
Primary KPIs:
- Click-Through Rate (CTR)
- Engagement Rate
- Site Traffic (sessions, users)
- Content Consumption (video views, downloads, time on site)

Secondary KPIs:
- Cost Per Click (CPC)
- Cost Per Engagement
- Bounce Rate
- Pages Per Session
- Return Visit Rate

Benchmarks and Targets:
- CTR varies significantly by channel and format
- Display: 0.1-0.3 percent
- Social: 0.5-1.5 percent
- Search: 2-5 percent
- Native: 0.3-0.8 percent
- Bounce rate under 50 percent for quality traffic

Primary KPIs:
- Conversion Rate
- Cost Per Acquisition (CPA/CAC)
- Return on Ad Spend (ROAS)
- Revenue/Pipeline Generated

Secondary KPIs:
- Cost Per Click
- Click to Conversion Rate
- Average Order Value
- Customer Lifetime Value (LTV)
- LTV to CAC Ratio

Benchmarks and Targets:
- ROAS targets vary dramatically by vertical and margin
- Low margin retail: 4-6x ROAS target
- High margin SaaS: 1-2x ROAS acceptable if LTV supports
- LTV to CAC ratio: 3:1 minimum for sustainability
- Conversion rate: 2-5 percent ecommerce, 10-20 percent lead gen

Primary KPIs:
- Customer Retention Rate
- Repeat Purchase Rate
- Customer Lifetime Value
- Net Promoter Score

Secondary KPIs:
- Email Open and Click Rates
- App Retention (Day 1, 7, 30)
- Subscription Renewal Rate
- Referral Rate

PLATFORM-SPECIFIC MEASUREMENT CONSIDERATIONS

META (FACEBOOK/INSTAGRAM)

Attribution Defaults:
- 7-day click, 1-day view default
- Can extend to 28-day click, 1-day view
- View-through for video and awareness campaigns

Measurement Tools:
- Experiments (conversion lift)
- Brand Lift Studies
- Marketing Mix Modeling partnerships
- Conversion API integration

Known Limitations:
- iOS 14.5 plus opt-out reduces tracking
- View-through attribution inflated for some advertisers
- Modeled conversions fill data gaps

Recommendations:
- Implement Conversions API
- Use conversion lift for incrementality validation
- Consider 7-day click as primary, view-through as supplemental

Attribution Defaults:
- Data-driven attribution default for accounts with sufficient data
- Last-click fallback for limited conversion data
- 30-day default lookback (adjustable 1-90 days)

Measurement Tools:
- Google Analytics 4 integration
- Conversion Lift experiments
- Search Lift studies
- Offline conversion import

Known Limitations:
- Cross-device gaps
- YouTube view-through methodology
- Performance Max black box attribution

Recommendations:
- Enable enhanced conversions
- Implement GA4 with consent mode
- Use value-based bidding with accurate conversion values

Attribution Defaults:
- 30-day click, 7-day view default
- 90-day options available for longer cycles
- Last-touch primary model

Measurement Tools:
- Website demographics
- Conversion tracking
- Matched audiences
- Company engagement reports

Known Limitations:
- Limited view-through transparency
- B2B cycles often exceed lookback windows
- Account-level attribution challenging

Recommendations:
- Use longer lookback windows for B2B
- Implement offline conversions from CRM
- Focus on lead quality not just volume

Attribution Defaults:
- Varies by DSP
- Typically last-touch with view-through
- Custom windows available

Measurement Tools:
- Cross-device graphs
- Third-party measurement (DoubleVerify, IAS, Moat)
- Brand lift integrations
- Log-level data for custom analysis

Known Limitations:
- Fragmented identity resolution
- View-through inflation risk
- Cross-platform deduplication

Recommendations:
- Implement strict viewability thresholds
- Use conservative view-through windows
- Deduplicate across platforms

LEVEL 1: BASIC

Characteristics:
- Platform-native reporting only
- Last-click attribution
- Basic conversion tracking
- Manual reporting

Recommended Focus:
- Implement consistent conversion tracking
- Establish baseline metrics
- Define success criteria

LEVEL 2: DEVELOPING

Characteristics:
- Cross-platform reporting dashboard
- Multi-touch attribution consideration
- Enhanced conversion tracking
- Regular optimization cadence

Recommended Focus:
- Implement multi-touch model
- Add server-side tracking
- Begin holdout testing

LEVEL 3: ADVANCED

Characteristics:
- Unified measurement framework
- MTA plus MMM integration
- Regular incrementality testing
- Automated reporting and alerting

Recommended Focus:
- Triangulate across methods
- Implement geo experiments
- Build predictive models

LEVEL 4: SOPHISTICATED

Characteristics:
- Full measurement trinity
- Real-time optimization
- Unified identity resolution
- Causal inference standard practice

Recommended Focus:
- Continuous experimentation culture
- AI-powered optimization
- Privacy-safe measurement innovation

OVER-ATTRIBUTION

Symptoms:
- Sum of attributed conversions exceeds actual conversions
- Every channel claims full credit
- Impossible ROAS across all channels

Solutions:
- Implement deduplication
- Use fractional attribution
- Validate with holdout tests

UNDER-ATTRIBUTION OF AWARENESS

Symptoms:
- Brand campaigns show poor ROAS
- Cutting awareness kills performance over time
- Search and retargeting get all credit

Solutions:
- Use first-touch model for awareness evaluation
- Implement brand lift studies
- Run awareness holdout tests

Symptoms:
- Different platforms report different numbers
- Cannot reconcile platform data with analytics
- Total attributed exceeds actual sales

Solutions:
- Establish single source of truth
- Apply consistent attribution windows
- Use independent measurement

Symptoms:
- Declining reported conversions despite stable revenue
- Increasing modeled versus observed conversions
- Cross-device journeys fragmented

Solutions:
- Implement server-side tracking
- Enable enhanced conversions
- Supplement with MMM

PRIVACY-FIRST MEASUREMENT

Third-Party Cookie Deprecation:
- Chrome phasing out (timeline evolving)
- Safari and Firefox already blocked
- Mobile IDFA opt-in required

Privacy Regulations:
- GDPR (Europe)
- CCPA/CPRA (California)
- State-level regulations expanding
- Global privacy frameworks emerging

PRIVACY-SAFE MEASUREMENT APPROACHES

Aggregated Measurement:
- Privacy Sandbox APIs (Topics, Attribution Reporting)
- Aggregated conversion reporting
- Differential privacy techniques

First-Party Data Strategy:
- Consent-based data collection
- Customer data platforms
- Enhanced conversion matching

Contextual Signals:
- Content-based targeting measurement
- Contextual relevance scoring
- Publisher first-party data

Modeling and Estimation:
- Conversion modeling for gaps
- MMM for aggregate attribution
- Statistical inference methods

Required For:
- Major budget allocation decisions
- New channel evaluation
- Validating MMM findings
- Challenging platform attribution claims

Test Types:
- Geo holdouts (geographic regions without media)
- Ghost ads (bid in auction, do not serve)
- Conversion lift (platform-run experiments)
- Matched market tests
sectionTitle: INCREMENTALITY TESTING GUIDANCE WHEN TO RUN INCREMENTALITY TESTS

content:
Statistical Power:
- Ensure sufficient sample size for detection
- Define minimum detectable effect in advance
- Run for adequate duration

Control Group Integrity:
- True holdout from all treatment
- Match treatment and control characteristics
- Monitor for contamination

Incremental Lift Calculation:
- Lift = (Test Conversions - Control Conversions) / Control Conversions
- Report confidence intervals
- Consider statistical significance

Typical Incremental Ranges by Channel:
- Brand Search: 20-40 percent incremental
- Non-Brand Search: 60-80 percent incremental
- Retargeting: 30-50 percent incremental
- Prospecting Display: 50-70 percent incremental
- Social Prospecting: 55-75 percent incremental
- CTV/Video: 40-60 percent incremental

User context overrides framework guidance when:
- Organizational measurement maturity differs from recommendation
- Data availability limits implementation options
- Industry-specific requirements apply
- User has validated alternative approaches

Agent response to deviation requests:
- Present recommended approach with rationale
- Acknowledge practical constraints
- Proceed with user direction
- Suggest improvement path for future

Measurement strategy should match campaign objectives and organizational maturity. Use the measurement trinity (MMM, MTA, Incrementality) for comprehensive understanding. Select attribution models based on campaign type and sales cycle. Implement privacy-first tracking for future-proof measurement. Triangulate findings across methods for confidence. When guidance is missing, apply general principles and research current practices. Adapt to user context while sharing best practices.

DOCUMENT: MPA_Adaptive_Language_v5_5.txt
CATEGORY: Behavioral
TOPICS: language adaptation, sophistication, vocabulary, communication style

sectionTitle: DOCUMENT TYPE KNOWLEDGE BASE BEHAVIORAL GUIDE

content:
================================================================================

This document provides guidance on matching language complexity to user sophistication. The agent MUST adapt vocabulary, explanation depth, and technical terminology based on signals from user inputs.

================================================================================

User demonstrates simple sophistication when their input contains everyday language without industry jargon, round numbers without precision, casual phrasing like want more customers or get sales, questions that reveal unfamiliarity with marketing concepts, or no mention of metrics like CAC ROAS LTV CPA.

Example simple inputs: We sell shoes online and want more customers. Budget is 100K. We need to run some ads. How do we get more people to buy.

User demonstrates high sophistication when their input contains industry terminology used correctly, specific metrics with context like LTV CAC ratio or contribution margin, unit economics discussion, precise numbers with business logic, or references to attribution incrementality or optimization.

Example sophisticated inputs: Our LTV CAC is 2.8x with 15 percent contribution margin. We need to hit 75 dollar CAC to maintain unit economics at scale. Current blended ROAS is 3.2 but we suspect platform inflation.

================================================================================

================================================================================

When sophisticationLevel equals basic, these rules are MANDATORY.

Replace CAC with cost per customer.
Replace LTV with customer value or what a customer is worth.
Replace ROAS with return on your ad spend.
Replace acquisition efficiency with how much you can spend to get a customer.

When a basic user provides NEW quantitative data, recalculate and show what
it means - using simple terms.

Example - user changes a target:
User: We need at least 2,500 customers instead of 2,000.
Response: Let me update. $100,000 / 2,500 = $40 per customer. That is more
aggressive than typical $50-80 for shoe retail. To hit 2,500, we would need
tighter targeting or about $125K budget. Which makes more sense?

When a basic user says I do not know or shows uncertainty:
1. DO NOT ask follow-up questions about data they do not have

Example of CORRECT handling:
User: I am not sure about my profit margin.
Response: For shoe retailers, margins typically run 40 to 50 percent. Let me
model at 45 percent. You can adjust anytime.

Example of INCORRECT handling:
User: I am not sure about my profit margin.
WRONG Response: What profit margin do you typically see on a sale.

================================================================================
sectionTitle: 4. MOVE ON to the next question

content:
Match their vocabulary. If they say CAC, say CAC. If they discuss contribution margin, engage at that level.

Skip basic definitions. Do not explain what LTV means to someone who just quoted their LTV CAC ratio.

Engage with their framework. If they mention unit economics, respond in unit economics terms.

Challenge and refine at their level. Example: Your 2.8x LTV CAC is healthy, but at 15 percent contribution margin, you need roughly 7x payback on ad spend to break even. Are you seeing that in your current mix.

User: Our LTV CAC is currently 2.8x with 15 percent contribution margin. We need to hit 75 dollar CAC to maintain unit economics at scale.

Response: At 2.8x LTV CAC with 15 percent contribution, your effective payback is around 42 percent of LTV, which is tight but workable. The 75 dollar CAC ceiling makes sense. What is your current blended CAC running, and where do you see the most efficiency headroom. Are there channels where you are significantly below 75 that could absorb more spend, or is the constraint more about scale than efficiency.

================================================================================

================================================================================

When using ANY acronym for the first time in a conversation, define it with a parenthetical.

CAC: cost per customer or customer acquisition cost
LTV: lifetime value or customer lifetime value
ROAS: return on ad spend
CPA: cost per acquisition
CPM: cost per thousand impressions
CTR: click through rate
CVR: conversion rate

Use parenthetical definition on first use.

Correct examples:
Your CAC (cost per customer) of $80 is within benchmark.
$320 LTV (lifetime value) means strong unit economics.
At 4:1 LTV/CAC (lifetime value to cost per customer) ratio, you have flexibility.

For basic users: ALWAYS define on first use.
For intermediate users: ALWAYS define on first use.
For sophisticated users: Definition is optional if user already used the term.

If user introduces the acronym first, you may use it without defining.
Example: User says Our CAC is $50 - you can respond with CAC without definition.

================================================================================

================================================================================

When sophistication level is unclear, default to simpler language. Users will signal if they want more technical depth.

Watch for mid-conversation signals. A user who started simple may reveal sophistication as they engage. Adjust accordingly.

Never condescend. Simple language does not mean dumbed down. It means clear and accessible.

================================================================================

AUDIENCE DIMENSION CHECKLIST v5.8

VERSION 5.8
DATE January 2026
STATUS Production Ready
DOCUMENT TYPE Knowledge Base - Step 3 Audience Validation
COMPLIANCE 6-Rule Compliant

This document defines the mandatory requirements for complete audience definition in Step 3. The agent MUST verify all four dimensions are addressed and signal count thresholds are met before proceeding to Step 4 Geography.

Incomplete audience definition leads to wasted media spend. Every audience specification must cover four dimensions with sufficient signals for the campaign type. Census-validated sizing and platform taxonomy codes are required for activation-ready outputs.

The agent MUST verify coverage across all four dimensions before completing Step 3.

DIMENSION 1 DEMOGRAPHIC

Required signals:
- Age range with specific bounds
- Gender if relevant
- Household income tier
- Education level if relevant
- Homeownership status if relevant
- Presence of children if relevant
- Life stage indicators

DIMENSION 2 BEHAVIORAL

Required signals:
- In-market purchase intent categories
- Content consumption patterns
- Past purchase history indicators
- Site visitation behavior
- App usage patterns
- Search behavior indicators
- Engagement patterns

DIMENSION 3 CONTEXTUAL

Required signals:
- Daypart targeting preferences
- Device targeting requirements
- Content category alignment
- Weather-based triggers if applicable
- Seasonal patterns
- Event-based triggers

DIMENSION 4 GEOGRAPHIC

Required signals:
- Country or countries
- Region or state level
- DMA or market level
- Urban versus suburban versus rural
- Language preferences by geography

Brand Awareness Campaigns: 5-10 signals total
Performance Campaigns: 20-40 signals total
Consideration Campaigns: 10-20 signals total

The agent must count signals across all four dimensions and verify the total meets threshold for campaign type.
The agent MUST search for current census and population data when defining audience sizing. This is not optional.

United States
- Primary: US Census Bureau American Community Survey
- Search: site:census.gov [demographic] [DMA] population
- Tables: B01003 Total Population, B03002 Hispanic Origin, B19001 Income, S0101 Age

Canada
- Primary: Statistics Canada
- Search: site:statcan.gc.ca [CMA] population [demographic]

United Kingdom
- Primary: Office for National Statistics
- Search: site:ons.gov.uk [region] population [demographic]

European Union
- Primary: Eurostat plus national offices
- Search: site:ec.europa.eu/eurostat [country] [demographic]

Australia
- Primary: Australian Bureau of Statistics
- Search: site:abs.gov.au [state] population [demographic]

Every audience size estimate must cite:
- Source name and organization
- Geographic level of data
- Data year or range
- Specific table reference if applicable

Step 1 - Get total population from census
Step 2 - Apply demographic filters as percentage reductions
Step 3 - Apply behavioral filters as percentage reductions
Step 4 - Result is estimated addressable audience

Example calculation:
- LA DMA total: 13,200,000 (Census ACS 2019-2023)
- Age 25-54: 40% = 5,280,000
- HHI over 50K: 45% = 2,376,000
- Hispanic origin: 45% = 1,069,200
- In-market financial: 6% = 64,152
- Target audience: 64,152 (0.5% of DMA)
The agent MUST produce platform-specific codes for activation. Web search for current codes rather than relying on potentially outdated information.

Tier 1: IAB-[number] [Category Name]
Tier 2: IAB-[number]-[number] [Subcategory Name]
Example: IAB13 Personal Finance, IAB13-7 Investing

Search pattern: IAB content taxonomy [category] code number

Affinity: /Affinity/[Category]/[Subcategory]
In-Market: /In-Market/[Category]/[Subcategory]
Custom Intent: Keywords + URLs

Interests: [Interest1], [Interest2]
Behaviors: [Behavior1], [Behavior2]

Search pattern: Facebook detailed targeting [interest] options

Job Functions: [Function1], [Function2]

Company Size: [Size range]
Seniority: [Level1], [Level2]

Search pattern: LinkedIn Campaign Manager targeting [attribute] options

The agent MUST search for current taxonomy codes before presenting audience specification. Do not assume codes are correct without verification.

Search triggers:
- Any audience definition requiring platform targeting
- Any request for activation-ready specifications
- Any uncertainty about current taxonomy codes

When Step 3 is complete, present the following summary:

Target Description: 2-3 sentences describing the ideal customer

Demographic Profile:

Data Sources:

- Presenting audience sizes without census validation
- Omitting taxonomy codes that enable direct activation
- Using outdated population data when current census available
- Defining only demographic signals without behavioral
- Missing geographic dimension entirely
- Not showing calculation methodology
- Failing to verify signal count meets threshold

Before completing Step 3, verify:
- All four dimensions have at least one signal
- Signal count meets threshold for campaign type
- Population data cites census source

- Taxonomy codes are included
- Geographic scope is defined

Rule 1 - Search before assuming
Never assume a taxonomy code is correct. Always verify with web search.

Rule 2 - Cite every data point

Rule 3 - Prefer official sources

Rule 5 - Flag uncertainty
If search does not return definitive results, note this in the specification.
